column2: image_caption          = Post office in downtown Battleford
subdivision_type4      = [[List of rural municipalities in Saskatchewan
unit_pref                = <!--Enter: Imperial, if Imperial (metric) is desired-->
2011 population]] 4,065) is a small town located across the [[North Saskatchewan River]] from the City of [[North Battleford]], in [[Saskatchewan]], Canada.

column1: Battleford and North Battleford are collectively referred to as \"The Battlefords\" by Saskatchewan residents, as well as on highway signage. Although there has been occasional talk of the two communities merging, as of 2012 they remain separate entities. The local economy is fuelled mainly by agriculture. Battleford is bordered by the [[Battle River No. 438, Saskatchewan
column2: Rural Municipality of Battle River No. 438]], as well as by the city of North Battleford and a small section of the [[North Battleford No. 437, Saskatchewan
column3: Rural Municipality of North Battleford No. 437]].

column1: The 1973 western ''[[Alien Thunder]]'' was partially filmed in Battleford.

column2: cellpadding=\"1\" style=\"float:right; margin:0 1em 1em 0; border:1px #bbb solid; border-collapse:collapse; font-size:90%;\"
History of Northwest Territories capital cities}}

column1: The Battleford area was the site of numerous independent and Hudson's Bay Company fur trading houses dating from the 1770s.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Historic Forts of the French Regime and of the English Fur Trading Companies
column7: website=Historic Forts of the French Regime and of the English Fur Trading Companies
column16: access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref> operated a post for the North West Company just above the confluence of the Battle and Saskatchewan rivers in 1784.<ref>{{Cite book
column17: title=A History of the Canadian West
column23: pages=337 ff}}</ref> At least three posts were in use between 1868 and 1914.<ref>{{Cite book
column32: pages=Map of Trading Posts pre 1759 – post 1930
column33: nopp=y}}</ref> The town was founded in 1875 as a [[Fur trade
column34: fur trading]] post and [[North-West Mounted Police]] (NWMP) fort. Its post office opened in 1877.<ref>{{cite web

column2: publisher = Canadian Plains Research Center, [[University of Regina]]

column1: }}</ref> Between 1876 and 1883, Battleford was the territorial capital of the North-West Territories (now [[Alberta]], [[Saskatchewan]], [[Nunavut]], northern [[Quebec]], northern [[Ontario]] and the [[Northwest Territories]]) and the NWMP fort ([[Fort Battleford]]) located there played an important role in the 1885 [[North-West Rebellion]].  It is also the terminus of the historic [[Swift Current-Battleford Trail]].

column2: 1885]], during the [[North-West Rebellion]], the town of Battleford was looted by a party of [[Cree people]], who were short on food due to declining [[bison]] populations. When the Cree approached Battleford, the 500 residents<ref>{{Citation

title = McPhillips' alphabetical and business directory of the district of Saskatchewan, N.W.T.: Together with brief historical sketches of Prince Albert, Battleford and the other settlements in the district, 1888 (p. 53)

column1: }}</ref> fled to the nearby [[North-West Mounted Police]] post, [[Fort Battleford]].  The Crees then took food and supplies from the abandoned stores and houses.

column2: List of historic places in Battleford}}

column1: National historic sites in Battleford include [[Fort Battleford]] National Historic Site of Canada,<ref>{{CRHP
column4: 2013-12-07}}</ref> [[Battleford Court House]] National Historic Site of Canada<ref>{{CRHP
column7: 2013-12-07}}</ref> and Old Government House / Saint-Charles Scholasticate National Historic Site of Canada. The Old Government House, built in 1878-1879, was destroyed by fire in 2003 and was the seat of Territorial Government from 1878 to 1883<ref>{{CRHP

column1: The Battleford Land Registry Office built between 1877-1878 is the last remaining building on Battleford's Government Ridge that dates from the Territorial era.<ref>{{CRHP
Other heritage buildings include the District Court House,<ref>{{CRHP
column13: 2013-12-07}}</ref> the Fred Light Museum (St. Vital School),<ref>{{CRHP
column22: 2013-12-07}}</ref> and the Former Bank of Montreal Building.<ref>{{CRHP

column1: The local newspaper is ''[[The Battlefords News Optimist]]''. It is published weekly on Wednesdays and Fridays, and has circulation in the surrounding area.
Three local radio stations serve the area; [[CJNB]], [[CJCQ-FM]] (\"Q98\"), and [[CJHD-FM]] (\"93.3 The Rock\"). Some [[Saskatoon]] radio stations can also be received.
The Battlefords are served by CFQC-TV-2 channel 6, an analogue repeater of [[CTV Television Network

changing some notation from old italicized to more readable TeX,safe,Phokoro,"In [[mathematics]], a '''volume form''' on a [[differentiable manifold]] is a top-dimensional form (i.e., a [[differential form]] of top degree).   Thus on a manifold <math>M</math> of dimension <math>n</math>, a volume form is an <math>n</math>-form, a [[section (fiber bundle)
column2: section]] of the [[line bundle]] <math>\\Omega^n(M)=\\bigwedge^n(T^*M)</math>.  A manifold admits a nowhere-vanishing volume form if and only if it is orientable. An [[orientable manifold]] has infinitely many volume forms, since multiplying a volume form by a function yields another volume form. On non-orientable manifolds, one may instead define the weaker notion of a [[Density on a manifold

column1: A volume form provides a means to define the [[integral]] of a [[Function (mathematics)
column2: function]] on a differentiable manifold.  In other words, a volume form gives rise to a [[measure (mathematics)
column3: measure]] with respect to which functions can be integrated by the appropriate [[Lebesgue integral]].  The absolute value of a volume form is a [[volume element]], which is also known variously as a ''twisted volume form'' or ''pseudo-volume form''.  It also defines a measure, but exists on any differentiable manifold, orientable or not.

column1: [[Kähler manifold]]s, being [[complex manifold]]s, are naturally oriented, and so possess a volume form.  More generally, the <math>n</math>th [[exterior power]] of the symplectic form on a [[symplectic manifold]] is a volume form. Many classes of manifolds have canonical volume forms: they have extra structure which allows the choice of a preferred volume form.  Oriented [[pseudo-Riemannian manifold]]s have an associated canonical volume form.

A manifold is [[orientable]] if it has a [[coordinate atlas]] all of whose transition functions have positive [[Jacobian determinant]]s.  A selection of a maximal such atlas is an orientation on <math>M</math>.  A volume form <math>\\omega</math> on <math>M</math> gives rise to an orientation in a natural way as the atlas of coordinate charts on <math>M</math> that send <math>\\omega</math> to a positive multiple of the Euclidean volume form <math>dx^1\\wedge\\cdots\\wedge dx^n</math>.
A volume form also allows for the specification of a preferred class of [[moving frame
column2: frames]] on <math>M</math>. Call a basis of tangent vectors <math>(X_1, \\ldots, X_n)</math> right-handed if

column1: The collection of all right-handed frames is [[Group action (mathematics)
column4: general linear]] mappings in <math>n</math> dimensions with positive determinant.  They form a [[principal bundle
column5: principal <math>GL^+(n)</math> sub-bundle]] of the [[linear frame bundle]] of <math>M</math>, and so the orientation associated to a volume form gives a canonical reduction of the frame bundle of <math>M</math> to a sub-bundle with structure group <math>GL^+(n)</math>.  That is to say that a volume form gives rise to [[G-structure
column6: <math>GL^+(n)</math>-structure]] on <math>M</math>.  More reduction is clearly possible by considering frames that have

column1: Thus a volume form gives rise to an <math>SL(n)</math>-structure as well.  Conversely, given an <math>SL(n)</math>-structure, one can recover a volume form by imposing ({{EquationNote
column2: 1}}) for the special linear frames and then solving for the required <math>n</math>-form <math>\\omega</math> by requiring homogeneity in its arguments.

column1: A manifold is orientable if and only if it has a volume form.  Indeed, <math>SL(n) \\to GL^+(n)</math> is a [[deformation retract]] since <math>GL^+ = SL \\times \\mathbb{R}^+</math>, where the [[positive reals]] are embedded as scalar matrices.  Thus every <math>GL^+(n)</math>-structure is reducible to an <math>SL(n)</math>-structure, and <math>GL^+(n)</math>-structures coincide with orientations on <math>M</math>.  More concretely, triviality of the determinant bundle <math>\\Omega^n(M)</math> is equivalent to orientability, and a line bundle is trivial if and only if it has a nowhere-vanishing section. Thus the existence of a volume form is equivalent to orientability.
Given a volume form <math>\\omega</math> on an oriented manifold, the [[density on a manifold
column5: pseudo-form]] on the nonoriented manifold obtained by forgetting the orientation. Densities may also be defined more generally on non-orientable manifolds.

column1: Any volume pseudo-form <math>\\omega</math> (and therefore also any volume form) defines a measure on the [[Borel set]]s by

The difference is that while a measure can be integrated over a (Borel) ''subset'', a volume form can only be integrated over an ''oriented'' cell. In single variable [[calculus]], writing <math>\\int_b^a f\\,dx = -\\int_a^b f\\,dx</math> considers <math>dx</math> as a volume form, not simply a measure, and <math>\\int_b^a</math> indicates \"integrate over the cell <math>[a,b]</math> with the opposite orientation, sometimes denoted <math>\\overline{[a,b]}</math>\".

Further, general measures need not be continuous or smooth: they need not be defined by a volume form, or more formally, their [[Radon–Nikodym derivative]] with respect to a given volume form need not be [[absolutely continuous]].
Given a volume form ''ω'' on ''M'', one can define the [[divergence]] of a [[vector field]] ''X'' as the unique scalar-valued function, denoted by div ''X'', satisfying
where ''L''<sub>''X''</sub> denotes the [[Lie derivative]] along ''X'' and <math>X\\;\\lrcorner\\;\\omega</math> denotes the [[interior product]] or the left [[tensor contraction
column2: contraction]] of ''ω'' along ''X''. If ''X'' is a [[compact support
column3: compactly supported]] vector field and ''M'' is a [[manifold with boundary]], then [[Stokes' theorem]] implies

column1: which is a generalization of the [[divergence theorem]].
The [[solenoidal]] vector fields are those with {{nowrap
column2: 1=div ''X'' = 0}}.  It follows from the definition of the Lie derivative that the volume form is preserved under the [[vector flow
column3: flow]] of a solenoidal vector field.  Thus solenoidal vector fields are precisely those that have volume-preserving flows.  This fact is well-known, for instance, in [[fluid mechanics]] where the divergence of a velocity field measures the compressibility of a fluid, which in turn represents the extent to which volume is preserved along flows of the fluid.

column1: For any [[Lie group]], a natural volume form may be defined by translation.  That is, if ''ω''<sub>''e''</sub> is an element of <math>{\\textstyle\\bigwedge}^n T_e^*G</math>, then a left-invariant form may be defined by <math>\\omega_g=L_{g^{-1}}^*\\omega_e</math>, where ''L''<sub>''g''</sub> is left-translation.  As a corollary, every Lie group is orientable.  This volume form is unique up to a scalar, and the corresponding measure is known as the [[Haar measure]].

Any [[symplectic manifold]] (or indeed any [[almost symplectic manifold]]) has a natural volume form.  If ''M'' is a 2''n''-dimensional manifold with [[symplectic form]] ''ω'', then ''ω''<sup>''n''</sup> is nowhere zero as a consequence of the [[nondegeneracy]] of the symplectic form.  As a corollary, any symplectic manifold is orientable (indeed, oriented).  If the manifold is both symplectic and Riemannian, then the two volume forms agree if the manifold is [[Kähler manifold

column4: Riemannian]]) [[manifold]] has a natural volume form.  In [[local coordinates]], it can be expressed as

column1: where the <math>dx^i</math> are [[1-form]]s that form a positively oriented basis for the [[cotangent bundle]] of the manifold.  Here, <math>
column3: </math> is the absolute value of the [[determinant]] of the matrix representation of the [[metric tensor]] on the manifold.

column1: The volume form is denoted variously by

Here, the <math>{\\star}</math> is the [[Hodge star]], thus the last form, <math>{\\star} (1)</math>, emphasizes that the volume form is the Hodge dual of the constant map on the manifold, which equals the [[Levi-Civita tensor

Although the Greek letter ''ω'' is frequently used to denote the volume form, this notation is not universal; the symbol ''ω'' often carries many other meanings in [[differential geometry]] (such as a symplectic form).
Volume forms are not unique; they form a [[torsor]] over non-vanishing functions on the manifold, as follows. Given a non-vanishing function ''f'' on ''M'', and a volume form <math>\\omega</math>,

<math>f\\omega</math> is a volume form on ''M''. Conversely, given two volume forms <math>\\omega, \\omega'</math>, their ratio is a non-vanishing function (positive if they define the same orientation, negative if they define opposite orientations).

In coordinates, they are both simply a non-zero function times [[Lebesgue measure]], and their ratio is the ratio of the functions, which is independent of choice of coordinates. Intrinsically, it is the [[Radon–Nikodym theorem#Radon.E2.80.93Nikodym derivative
column2: Radon–Nikodym derivative]] of <math>\\omega'</math> with respect to <math>\\omega</math>.  On an oriented manifold, the proportionality of any two volume forms can be thought of as a geometric form of the [[Radon–Nikodym theorem]].

column1: A volume form on a manifold has no local structure in the sense that it is not possible on small open sets to distinguish between the given volume form and the volume form on Euclidean space {{harv
column3: 1972}}.  That is, for every point ''p'' in ''M'', there is an open neighborhood ''U'' of ''p'' and a [[diffeomorphism]] ''φ'' of ''U'' onto an open set in '''R'''<sup>''n''</sup> such that the volume form on ''U'' is the [[pullback]] of <math>dx^1\\wedge\\cdots\\wedge dx^n</math> along ''φ''.

column1: As a corollary, if ''M'' and ''N'' are two manifolds, each with volume forms <math>\\omega_M, \\omega_N</math>, then for any points <math>m\\in M, n\\in N</math>, there are open neighborhoods ''U'' of ''m'' and ''V'' of ''n'' and a map <math>f\\colon U \\to V</math> such that the volume form on ''N'' restricted to the neighborhood ''V'' pulls back to volume form on ''M'' restricted to the neighborhood ''U'': <math>f^*\\omega_N\\vert_V = \\omega_M\\vert_U</math>.
In one dimension, one can prove it thus:
given a volume form <math>\\omega</math> on <math>\\mathbf{R}</math>, define

column2: pulls back]] to <math>\\omega</math> under ''f'': <math>\\omega = f^*dx</math>. Concretely, <math>\\omega = f'\\,dx</math>.  In higher dimensions, given any point <math>m \\in M</math>, it has a neighborhood locally homeomorphic to <math>\\mathbf{R}\\times\\mathbf{R}^{n-1}</math>, and one can apply the same procedure.

column1: A volume form on a connected manifold ''M'' has a single global invariant, namely the (overall) volume (denoted <math>\\mu(M)</math>), which is invariant under volume-form preserving maps; this may be infinite, such as for Lebesgue measure on <math>\\mathbf{R}^n</math>. On a disconnected manifold, the volume of each connected component is the invariant.
In symbols, if <math>f\\colon M \\to N</math> is a homeomorphism of manifolds that pulls back <math>\\omega_N</math> to <math>\\omega_M</math>, then
and the manifolds have the same volume.

Volume forms can also be pulled back under [[covering map]]s, in which case they multiply volume by the cardinality of the fiber (formally, by integration along the fiber). In the case of an infinite sheeted cover (such as <math>\\mathbf{R} \\to S^1</math>), a volume form on a finite volume manifold pulls back to a volume form on an infinite volume manifold.
* [[Poincaré metric]] provides a review of the volume form on the [[complex plane]]

column1: A volume form on a manifold has no local structure in the sense that it is not possible on small open sets to distinguish between the given volume form and the volume form on Euclidean space {{harv
column3: 1972}}.  That is, for every point ''p'' in ''M'', there is an open neighborhood ''U'' of ''p'' and a [[diffeomorphism]] ''φ'' of ''U'' onto an open set in '''R'''<sup>''n''</sup> such that the volume form on ''U'' is the [[pullback]] of <math>dx^1\\wedge\\cdots\\wedge dx^n</math> along ''φ''.

column1: As a corollary, if ''M'' and ''N'' are two manifolds, each with volume forms <math>\\omega_M, \\omega_N</math>, then for any points <math>m\\in M, n\\in N</math>, there are open neighborhoods ''U'' of ''m'' and ''V'' of ''n'' and a map <math>f\\colon U \\to V</math> such that the volume form on ''N'' restricted to the neighborhood ''V'' pulls back to volume form on ''M'' restricted to the neighborhood ''U'': <math>f^*\\omega_N\\vert_V = \\omega_M\\vert_U</math>.
In one dimension, one can prove it thus:
given a volume form <math>\\omega</math> on <math>\\mathbf{R}</math>, define

column2: pulls back]] to <math>\\omega</math> under ''f'': <math>\\omega = f^*dx</math>. Concretely, <math>\\omega = f'\\,dx</math>.  In higher dimensions, given any point <math>m \\in M</math>, it has a neighborhood locally homeomorphic to <math>\\mathbf{R}\\times\\mathbf{R}^{n-1}</math>, and one can apply the same procedure.

column1: A volume form on a connected manifold ''M'' has a single global invariant, namely the (overall) volume (denoted <math>\\mu(M)</math>), which is invariant under volume-form preserving maps; this may be infinite, such as for Lebesgue measure on <math>\\mathbf{R}^n</math>. On a disconnected manifold, the volume of each connected component is the invariant.
In symbols, if <math>f\\colon M \\to N</math> is a homeomorphism of manifolds that pulls back <math>\\omega_N</math> to <math>\\omega_M</math>, then
and the manifolds have the same volume.

Volume forms can also be pulled back under [[covering map]]s, in which case they multiply volume by the cardinality of the fiber (formally, by integration along the fiber). In the case of an infinite sheeted cover (such as <math>\\mathbf{R} \\to S^1</math>), a volume form on a finite volume manifold pulls back to a volume form on an infinite volume manifold.
* [[Poincaré metric]] provides a review of the volume form on the [[complex plane]]

column7: ہنزہ}}}}) is a mountainous valley in the [[Gilgit-Baltistan
column8: Gilgit-Baltistan region]] of [[Pakistan]]. Hunza is situated in the extreme northern part of Pakistan, bordering with the [[Wakhan Corridor]] of [[Afghanistan]] and the [[Xinjiang
column10: title=Mountainous Valley situated in extreme northern part of Pakistan

column1: The Hunza valley is situated at an elevation of 2,438 meters (7,999 feet).  Geographicaly, Hunza consists of three regions, Upper Hunza ([[Gojal]]), Central Hunza (\"Hunza Valley\") and Lower Hunza (\"Shinaki\").
[[File: Baltit Fort, Karimabad, Hunza, Gilgit Baltistan.jpg
column3: [[Baltit Fort]], the former residence of the Mirs of Hunza]]

column1: Hunza was formerly a [[princely state]] bordering  [[Xinjiang]] (autonomous region of China) to the northeast and [[Pamir Mountains
column2: Pamir]] to the northwest, which survived until 1974, when it was finally dissolved by [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]].  The state bordered the [[Gilgit Agency]] to the south and the former princely state of [[Nagar (princely state)
column3: Nagar]] to the east. The state capital was the town of Baltit (also known as [[Karimabad (Hunza)
column4: Karimabad]]); another old settlement is [[Ganish Village]] which means \"ancient gold\" village. Hunza was an independent principality for more than 900 years until the [[British Raj
column5: British]] gained control of it and the neighboring valley of Nagar between 1889 and 1891 through military conquest. The then [[Tham (title)
column7: Katur Dynasty]], Safdar Khan of Hunza fled to [[Kashghar]] in China and sought what would now be called political asylum.<ref>{{cite web

column1: An account wrote by John Biddulph in his book ''[[Tribes of the Hindoo Koosh]]'' {{cquote
column2: The ruling family of Hunza is called Ayesha (heavenly). The two states of [[Hunza (princely state)
column4: Nagar]] were formerly one, ruled by a branch of the Shahreis, the ruling family of [[Gilgit]], whose seat of government was Nager. First muslim came to Hunza-Nagar Valley some 1000 years (At the time of Imam Islām Shāh 30th Imam Ismaili Muslims). After the introduction of [[Islam]] to Gilgit, married a daughter of Trakhan of [[Gilgit]], who bore him twin sons, named Moghlot and Girkis. From the former, the present ruling family of Nager is descended. The twins are said to have shown hostility to one another from birth. Thereupon their father, unable to settle the question of succession, divided his state between them, giving Girkis the north/west, and to Moghlot the south/east bank of the river.<ref>Tribes of the Hindoo Koosh by John Biddulph page 26</ref>}}

column1: In January 4, 2010, a landslide blocked the river and created [[Attabad Lake]] (also called shishket Lake), resulting in 20 deaths and 8 injuries and has effectively blocked about {{convert
column11: title=SHISHKET LAKE CRISES – 2010 – CHRONOLOGY OF EVENTS
column17: date=27 July 2010}}</ref> The new lake extends {{convert
column20: mi}} and rose to a depth of {{convert
column23: m}} when it was formed as the Hunza River backed up.<ref name=\"fourworlds_HiMaT_2013\">{{cite web
column25: title=Needed: a second green revolution in Hunza
column31: author2=Judie Bopp}} Karakorum Area Development Organization (KADO), Aliabad</ref> The landslide completely covered sections of the Karakoram Highway.<ref name=\"fourworlds_HiMaT_2013\" />

column1: On 1 July 2018, [[Pakistan Army]] pilots in a daring mission rescued 3 foreign mountaineers stuck in snow avalanche at above the height of {{Convert
column4: Ultar Sar Peak]] near Hunza. The perilous weather conditions had made it difficult for the Army helicopter to go forth with a rescue operation on the {{Convert
column6: m}} high [[Ultar Sar]]. But they completed it. Bruce Normand and Timothy Miller from [[United Kingdom
column7: UK]] successfully rescued alive while their companion Christian Huber from [[Austria]] had succumbed to avalanche.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Pakistan Army Pilots rescued 3 foreign mountaineers

column2: Thomas Drew]] in [[Pakistan]] termed the mission “remarkable and dangerous” and said:

column1: “''Our gratitude to the [[Pakistan Army]] pilots who rescued two British climbers trapped by an avalanche on [[Ultar Sar
column2: Ultar Sar Peak]] near Hunza. Our thoughts with their Austrian fellow climber who died”''.
title=Britain's High Commissioner in Pakistan admired Pak Army Pilots for rescued the two British Climbers
column6: title=Major General Asif Ghafoor also tweeted about it

column1: The local languages spoken include [[Burushaski]], [[Wakhi language
column3: Shina]]. The literacy rate of the Hunza valley is more than 95%.<ref name=\"education dawn\">{{cite news
column10: accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> The historical area of Hunza and present northern Pakistan has had, over the centuries, mass migrations, conflicts and resettling of tribes and ethnicities, of which the [[Shina people
column11: Dardic Shina]] race is the most prominent in regional history. People of the region have recounted their historical traditions down the generations. The Hunza Valley is also home to some [[Wakhi people
column12: Wakhi]], who migrated there from northeastern Afghanistan beginning in the nineteenth century onwards.<ref>{{Cite book
column13: title=The Arts and Crafts of the Hunza Valley in Pakistan: Living Traditions in the Karakoram

column1: The longevity of Hunza people has been noted by some,<ref name=\"Wrench1938\">{{Cite book
column4: title=The Wheel of Health: A Study of the Hunza People and the Keys to Health
column10: accessdate=12 August 2010 }}</ref> but others refute this as a [[Longevity myths
column11: longevity myth]] and cite a life expectancy of 110 years for men and 122 for women with a high standard deviation.<ref>{{cite news
column17: date=29 September 1996}}</ref> There is no evidence that Hunza life expectancy is significantly above the average of poor, isolated regions of Pakistan. Claims of health and long life were almost always based solely on the statements by the local mir (king). An author who had significant and sustained contact with Burusho people, John Clark, reported that they were overall unhealthy.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Hunza – The Truth, Myths, and Lies About the Health and Diet of the \"Long-Lived\" People of Hunza, Pakistan, Hunza Bread and Pie Recipes.

Thereupon their father, unable to settle the question of succession, divided his state between them, giving Girkis the north/west, and to Moghlot the south/east bank of the river.<ref>Tribes of the Hindoo Koosh by John Biddulph page 26</ref>}}

column1: In 2010, a landslide blocked the river and created [[Attabad Lake]] (also called shishket Lake), resulting in 20 deaths and 8 injuries and has effectively blocked about {{convert
column11: title=SHISHKET LAKE CRISES – 2010 – CHRONOLOGY OF EVENTS
column17: date=27 July 2010}}</ref> The new lake extends {{convert
column20: mi}} and rose to a depth of {{convert
column23: m}} when it was formed as the Hunza River backed up.<ref name=\"fourworlds_HiMaT_2013\">{{cite web
column25: title=Needed: a second green revolution in Hunza
column31: author2=Judie Bopp}} Karakorum Area Development Organization (KADO), Aliabad</ref> The landslide completely covered sections of the Karakoram Highway.<ref name=\"fourworlds_HiMaT_2013\" />

column1: On 1 July 2018, [[Pakistan Army]] pilots in a daring mission rescued 3 foreign mountaineers stuck in snow avalanche at above the height of {{Convert
column4: Ultar Sar Peak]] near Hunza. The perilous weather conditions had made it difficult for the Army helicopter to go forth with a rescue operation on the {{Convert
column6: m}} high [[Ultar Sar]]. But they completed it. Bruce Normand and Timothy Miller from [[United Kingdom
column7: UK]] successfully rescued alive while their companion Christian Huber from [[Austria]] had succumbed to avalanche.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Pakistan Army Pilots rescued 3 foreign mountaineers

column2: Thomas Drew]] in [[Pakistan]] termed the mission “remarkable and dangerous” and said:

column1: “''Our gratitude to the [[Pakistan Army]] pilots who rescued two British climbers trapped by an avalanche on [[Ultar Sar
column2: Ultar Sar Peak]] near Hunza. Our thoughts with their Austrian fellow climber who died”''.
title=Britain's High Commissioner in Pakistan admired Pak Army Pilots for rescued the two British Climbers
column6: title=Major General Asif Ghafoor also tweeted about it

column1: The local languages spoken include [[Burushaski]], [[Wakhi language
column3: Shina]]. The literacy rate of the Hunza valley is more than 77%.<ref name=\"education dawn\">{{cite news
column10: accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> The historical area of Hunza and present northern Pakistan has had, over the centuries, mass migrations, conflicts and resettling of tribes and ethnicities, of which the [[Shina people
column11: Dardic Shina]] race is the most prominent in regional history. People of the region have recounted their historical traditions down the generations. The Hunza Valley is also home to some [[Wakhi people
column12: Wakhi]], who migrated there from northeastern Afghanistan beginning in the nineteenth century onwards.<ref>{{Cite book
column13: title=The Arts and Crafts of the Hunza Valley in Pakistan: Living Traditions in the Karakoram

column1: The longevity of Hunza people has been noted by some,<ref name=\"Wrench1938\">{{Cite book
column4: title=The Wheel of Health: A Study of the Hunza People and the Keys to Health
column10: accessdate=12 August 2010 }}</ref> but others refute this as a [[Longevity myths
column11: longevity myth]] and cite a life expectancy of 110 years for men and 122 for women with a high standard deviation.<ref>{{cite news
column17: date=29 September 1996}}</ref> There is no evidence that Hunza life expectancy is significantly above the average of poor, isolated regions of Pakistan. Claims of health and long life were almost always based solely on the statements by the local mir (king). An author who had significant and sustained contact with Burusho people, John Clark, reported that they were overall unhealthy.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Hunza – The Truth, Myths, and Lies About the Health and Diet of the \"Long-Lived\" People of Hunza, Pakistan, Hunza Bread and Pie Recipes.

column1: The club was established as Christchurch Hampstead in 1908. They joined the Third Division of the Finchley & District League, which they won at the first attempt, earning promotion to Division Two.<ref name=H>[http://www.hendonfc.net/History History] Hendon F.C.</ref> At the start of the 1909–10 season the club were renamed Hampstead Town and they went on to win Division Two at the first attempt, earning promotion to Division One.<ref name=H/> For the 1911–12 season the club entered teams into both Division One of the Finchley & District League and Division Two of the London League.<ref name=H/><ref name=NLM1>[http://nonleaguematters.co.uk/nlmnet/Regmet/LoL10.html London League 1910–1928] Non-League Matters</ref> They won the Finchley & District League title, and a fourth-place finish in Division Two of the London League saw the club promoted to Division One.<ref name=H/><ref name=NLM1/> They subsequently entered a team into the Middlesex League alongside the London League team.

In 1912–13 Hampstead Town were runners-up in Division One of the London League, earning promotion to the Premier Division (Amateur);<ref name=NLM1/> they also won the Middlesex League.<ref name=Hon/> The following season saw them win both the Middlesex League and the Premier Division (Amateur) of the London League.<ref name=Hon/> This success saw the club admitted to the [[Athenian League]] for the 1914–15 season.<ref name=NLM1/><ref name=FCHD1>{{fchd
column3: name=Hampstead Town}}</ref> However, the league was abandoned after two games due to [[World War I]]. After the war they played in the [[United Senior League]] in the 1918–19 season and won the league,<ref>[http://www.historicaldons.com/index.php?od=5&yd=1912 1918–19] Historical Dons</ref> before returning to the Athenian League when it restarted in 1919. The club was renamed Hampstead in 1926.<ref name=FCHD1/> They were Athenian League runners-up in 1928–29 and again in 1932–33, before being renamed Golders Green in 1933.<ref name=FCHD2>{{fchd
column5: name=Hampstead}}</ref> They reached the first round of the [[FA Cup]] for the first time in [[1934–35 FA Cup
column6: 1934–35]], losing 10–1 at [[Football League Third Division South
column8: Southend United]].<ref name=FCHD2/> In 1946 the club was renamed again, adopting its current name,<ref name=FCHD2/> that of [[Hendon F.C. (1876)
column9: a club]] that existed in the 19th century.

column1: Hendon were Athenian League runners-up in 1947–48, 1948–49 and 1951–52 before winning their first Athenian League title in 1952–53, a season which also saw them reach the first round of the FA Cup again, losing 2–0 at [[Northampton Town F.C.
column2: Northampton Town]] in a replay.<ref name=FCHD3>{{fchd
column4: name=Hendon}}</ref> In 1954–55 they reached the final of the [[FA Amateur Cup]], losing 2–0 to [[Bishop Auckland F.C.
column6: Wembley]].<ref name=FCHD3/> They went on to win the Athenian League title again in 1955–56, also reaching the second round of the FA Cup, beating [[Halesowen Town F.C.
column7: Halesowen Town]] 4–2 in the first round before losing 6–2 at [[Exeter City F.C.
column8: Exeter City]] in the second.<ref name=FCHD3/> The club won their first Amateur Cup in 1959–60, defeating [[Kingstonian F.C.
column9: Kingstonian]] 2–1 in the final. A third Athenian League title was won in 1960–61.<ref name=FCHD3/> In 1963 the club switched to the [[Isthmian League]]. They were runners-up in their [[1963–64 Isthmian League
column10: first season]] in the league. In their second season, [[1964–65 Isthmian League
column11: 1964–65]], the club won the Isthmian League and Amateur Cup double, defeating [[Whitby Town F.C.

column1: Hendon reached the final of the FA Amateur Cup again the following season, but lost 3–1 to [[Wealdstone F.C.
column2: Wealdstone]]. After winning their third Amateur Cup with a 2–0 win against [[Enfield F.C.
column3: Enfield]] in 1971–72, a second Isthmian League title was won in [[1972–73 Isthmian League
column5: following season]] they reached the third round of the [[FA Cup]], where they drew [[Newcastle United F.C.
column6: Newcastle United]]; after holding them to a 1–1 draw at [[St James' Park]], Hendon lost 4–0 in a replay played at [[Watford F.C.
column7: Watford's]] [[Vicarage Road]].<ref name=FCHD3/> In [[1975–76 FA Cup
column8: 1975–76]] the club defeated a [[English Football League
column9: Football League]] club for the first time, beating [[Reading F.C.
column10: Reading]] 1–0 in the first round, before losing to [[Swindon Town F.C.
column11: Swindon Town]] in the second round.<ref name=FCHD3/>

column2: 2003–04]] Hendon finished fourth in the Isthmian League Premier Division but declined to join the new [[National League South
column3: Conference South]].<ref>[http://www.wsc.co.uk/the-archive/101-Non-League/2028-pyramid-schemes Pyramid schemes] When Saturday Comes</ref> Having remained in the top division of the Isthmian League since joining it in 1963, Hendon finished in the relegation zone at the end of the [[2005–06 Isthmian League
column4: 2005–06 season]], but were reprieved after [[Canvey Island F.C.
column5: Canvey Island]]'s resignation from the [[Football Conference]]. During the summer of 2010, the club was bought out by the Hendon FC Supporters Trust, an Industrial and Provident Society.<ref>{{cite web
column9: 2014–15]] they were Premier Division runners-up, qualifying for the promotion play-offs; after beating [[Metropolitan Police F.C.
column10: Metropolitan Police]] 2–1 in the semi-finals, they lost the final 1–0 to [[Margate F.C.
column12: 2017–18 season]] saw the club finish third in the Premier Division. In the subsequent play-offs, they defeated [[Folkestone Invicta F.C.
column13: Folkestone Invicta]] 4–0 in the semi-finals before losing the final 4–3 on penalties to [[Dulwich Hamlet F.C.
column14: Dulwich Hamlet]]. The club were placed in the Premier South Division of the [[Southern Football League
column15: Southern League]] for the [[2018–19 Southern Football League
column16: 2018–19 season]] as part of the restructuring of the non-League pyramid.

column1: The club moved to Claremont Road in [[Cricklewood]] in 1926. The first match was played on 18 September, an FA Cup game against [[Berkhamsted F.C.
column2: Berkhamsted]] that Hendon won 4–3.<ref name=H/> The ground was also briefly used by rugby league club [[London Broncos]].<ref>[http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/rugby/rugby-news/london-broncos-move-ealing-rfc-9743560 London Broncos to move to Ealing RFC] Get West London, 28 July 2015</ref> In the mid-2000s the ground was sold to property developers and it was initially planned that the club would move to [[Barnet Copthall]].<ref>[http://www.pyramidpassion.co.uk/html/snapshots__hendon_.html Snapshots - Hendon FC] Pyramid Passion</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150424164844/http://www.supporters-direct.org/faqs/hendon-fc Hendon] Supporters Direct</ref> However, the proposed move fell through and although Hendon had initially expected to leave in 2006, they were still at the ground in 2008; the final match at Claremont Road on 20 September 2008 saw local rivals [[Wealdstone F.C.

column1: After leaving Claremont Road Hendon played at [[Northwood F.C.
column3: Staines Town]]'s Wheatsheaf Road for the remainder of the 2008–09 season. They then moved to [[Wembley F.C.
column4: Wembley]]'s Vale Farm before relocating to [[Harrow Borough F.C.
column5: Harrow Borough]]'s Earlsmead ground in 2013.<ref>[http://www.pitchero.com/clubs/harrowborough/news/hendon-to-ground-share-at-harrow-borough-659019.html Hendon to ground share at Harrow Borough] Harrow Borough F.C.</ref> In 2016 they moved to Silver Jubilee Park in [[Kingsbury, London

→‎Orientation:adjusting appearance of notation from old italicized to more readable TeX,safe,Phokoro,"In [[mathematics]], a '''volume form''' on a [[differentiable manifold]] is a top-dimensional form (i.e., a [[differential form]] of top degree).   Thus on a manifold ''M'' of dimension ''n'', a volume form is an ''n''-form, a [[section (fiber bundle)
column3: 1=Ω<sup>''n''</sup>(''M'') = ⋀<sup>''n''</sup>(''T''<sup>∗</sup>''M'')}}.  A manifold admits a nowhere-vanishing volume form if and only if it is orientable. An [[orientable manifold]] has infinitely many volume forms, since multiplying a volume form by a function yields another volume form. On non-orientable manifolds, one may instead define the weaker notion of a [[Density on a manifold

column1: A volume form provides a means to define the [[integral]] of a [[Function (mathematics)
column2: function]] on a differentiable manifold.  In other words, a volume form gives rise to a [[measure (mathematics)
column3: measure]] with respect to which functions can be integrated by the appropriate [[Lebesgue integral]].  The absolute value of a volume form is a [[volume element]], which is also known variously as a ''twisted volume form'' or ''pseudo-volume form''.  It also defines a measure, but exists on any differentiable manifold, orientable or not.

column1: [[Kähler manifold]]s, being [[complex manifold]]s, are naturally oriented, and so possess a volume form.  More generally, the ''n''th [[exterior power]] of the symplectic form on a [[symplectic manifold]] is a volume form. Many classes of manifolds have canonical volume forms: they have extra structure which allows the choice of a preferred volume form.  Oriented [[pseudo-Riemannian manifold]]s have an associated canonical volume form.

A manifold is [[orientable]] if it has a [[coordinate atlas]] all of whose transition functions have positive [[Jacobian determinant]]s.  A selection of a maximal such atlas is an orientation on <math>M</math>.  A volume form <math>\\omega</math> on <math>M</math> gives rise to an orientation in a natural way as the atlas of coordinate charts on <math>M</math> that send <math>\\omega</math> to a positive multiple of the Euclidean volume form <math>dx^1\\wedge\\cdots\\wedge dx^n</math>.
A volume form also allows for the specification of a preferred class of [[moving frame
column2: frames]] on <math>M</math>. Call a basis of tangent vectors <math>(X_1, \\ldots, X_n)</math> right-handed if

column1: The collection of all right-handed frames is [[Group action (mathematics)
column4: general linear]] mappings in <math>n</math> dimensions with positive determinant.  They form a [[principal bundle
column5: principal <math>GL^+(n)</math> sub-bundle]] of the [[linear frame bundle]] of <math>M</math>, and so the orientation associated to a volume form gives a canonical reduction of the frame bundle of <math>M</math> to a sub-bundle with structure group <math>GL^+(n)</math>.  That is to say that a volume form gives rise to [[G-structure
column6: <math>GL^+(n)</math>-structure]] on <math>M</math>.  More reduction is clearly possible by considering frames that have

column1: Thus a volume form gives rise to an <math>SL(n)</math>-structure as well.  Conversely, given an <math>SL(n)</math>-structure, one can recover a volume form by imposing ({{EquationNote
column2: 1}}) for the special linear frames and then solving for the required <math>n</math>-form <math>\\omega</math> by requiring homogeneity in its arguments.

column1: A manifold is orientable if and only if it has a volume form.  Indeed, <math>SL(n) \\to GL^+(n)</math> is a [[deformation retract]] since <math>GL^+ = SL \\times \\mathbb{R}^+</math>, where the [[positive reals]] are embedded as scalar matrices.  Thus every <math>GL^+(n)</math>-structure is reducible to an <math>SL(n)</math>-structure, and <math>GL^+(n)</math>-structures coincide with orientations on <math>M</math>.  More concretely, triviality of the determinant bundle <math>\\Omega^n(M)</math> is equivalent to orientability, and a line bundle is trivial if and only if it has a nowhere-vanishing section. Thus the existence of a volume form is equivalent to orientability.
Given a volume form ''ω'' on an oriented manifold, the [[density on a manifold
column4: pseudo-form]] on the nonoriented manifold obtained by forgetting the orientation. Densities may also be defined more generally on non-orientable manifolds.

column1: Any volume pseudo-form ''ω'' (and therefore also any volume form) defines a measure on the [[Borel set]]s by

The difference is that while a measure can be integrated over a (Borel) ''subset'', a volume form can only be integrated over an ''oriented'' cell. In single variable [[calculus]], writing <math>\\int_b^a f\\,dx = -\\int_a^b f\\,dx</math> considers <math>dx</math> as a volume form, not simply a measure, and <math>\\int_b^a</math> indicates \"integrate over the cell <math>[a,b]</math> with the opposite orientation, sometimes denoted <math>\\overline{[a,b]}</math>\".

Further, general measures need not be continuous or smooth: they need not be defined by a volume form, or more formally, their [[Radon–Nikodym derivative]] with respect to a given volume form need not be [[absolutely continuous]].
Given a volume form ''ω'' on ''M'', one can define the [[divergence]] of a [[vector field]] ''X'' as the unique scalar-valued function, denoted by div ''X'', satisfying
where ''L''<sub>''X''</sub> denotes the [[Lie derivative]] along ''X'' and <math>X\\;\\lrcorner\\;\\omega</math> denotes the [[interior product]] or the left [[tensor contraction
column2: contraction]] of ''ω'' along ''X''. If ''X'' is a [[compact support
column3: compactly supported]] vector field and ''M'' is a [[manifold with boundary]], then [[Stokes' theorem]] implies

column1: which is a generalization of the [[divergence theorem]].
The [[solenoidal]] vector fields are those with {{nowrap
column2: 1=div ''X'' = 0}}.  It follows from the definition of the Lie derivative that the volume form is preserved under the [[vector flow
column3: flow]] of a solenoidal vector field.  Thus solenoidal vector fields are precisely those that have volume-preserving flows.  This fact is well-known, for instance, in [[fluid mechanics]] where the divergence of a velocity field measures the compressibility of a fluid, which in turn represents the extent to which volume is preserved along flows of the fluid.

column1: For any [[Lie group]], a natural volume form may be defined by translation.  That is, if ''ω''<sub>''e''</sub> is an element of <math>{\\textstyle\\bigwedge}^n T_e^*G</math>, then a left-invariant form may be defined by <math>\\omega_g=L_{g^{-1}}^*\\omega_e</math>, where ''L''<sub>''g''</sub> is left-translation.  As a corollary, every Lie group is orientable.  This volume form is unique up to a scalar, and the corresponding measure is known as the [[Haar measure]].

Any [[symplectic manifold]] (or indeed any [[almost symplectic manifold]]) has a natural volume form.  If ''M'' is a 2''n''-dimensional manifold with [[symplectic form]] ''ω'', then ''ω''<sup>''n''</sup> is nowhere zero as a consequence of the [[nondegeneracy]] of the symplectic form.  As a corollary, any symplectic manifold is orientable (indeed, oriented).  If the manifold is both symplectic and Riemannian, then the two volume forms agree if the manifold is [[Kähler manifold

column4: Riemannian]]) [[manifold]] has a natural volume form.  In [[local coordinates]], it can be expressed as

column1: where the <math>dx^i</math> are [[1-form]]s that form a positively oriented basis for the [[cotangent bundle]] of the manifold.  Here, <math>
column3: </math> is the absolute value of the [[determinant]] of the matrix representation of the [[metric tensor]] on the manifold.

column1: The volume form is denoted variously by

Here, the <math>{\\star}</math> is the [[Hodge star]], thus the last form, <math>{\\star} (1)</math>, emphasizes that the volume form is the Hodge dual of the constant map on the manifold, which equals the [[Levi-Civita tensor

Although the Greek letter ''ω'' is frequently used to denote the volume form, this notation is not universal; the symbol ''ω'' often carries many other meanings in [[differential geometry]] (such as a symplectic form).
Volume forms are not unique; they form a [[torsor]] over non-vanishing functions on the manifold, as follows. Given a non-vanishing function ''f'' on ''M'', and a volume form <math>\\omega</math>,

<math>f\\omega</math> is a volume form on ''M''. Conversely, given two volume forms <math>\\omega, \\omega'</math>, their ratio is a non-vanishing function (positive if they define the same orientation, negative if they define opposite orientations).

In coordinates, they are both simply a non-zero function times [[Lebesgue measure]], and their ratio is the ratio of the functions, which is independent of choice of coordinates. Intrinsically, it is the [[Radon–Nikodym theorem#Radon.E2.80.93Nikodym derivative
column2: Radon–Nikodym derivative]] of <math>\\omega'</math> with respect to <math>\\omega</math>.  On an oriented manifold, the proportionality of any two volume forms can be thought of as a geometric form of the [[Radon–Nikodym theorem]].

column1: A volume form on a manifold has no local structure in the sense that it is not possible on small open sets to distinguish between the given volume form and the volume form on Euclidean space {{harv
column3: 1972}}.  That is, for every point ''p'' in ''M'', there is an open neighborhood ''U'' of ''p'' and a [[diffeomorphism]] ''φ'' of ''U'' onto an open set in '''R'''<sup>''n''</sup> such that the volume form on ''U'' is the [[pullback]] of <math>dx^1\\wedge\\cdots\\wedge dx^n</math> along ''φ''.

column1: As a corollary, if ''M'' and ''N'' are two manifolds, each with volume forms <math>\\omega_M, \\omega_N</math>, then for any points <math>m\\in M, n\\in N</math>, there are open neighborhoods ''U'' of ''m'' and ''V'' of ''n'' and a map <math>f\\colon U \\to V</math> such that the volume form on ''N'' restricted to the neighborhood ''V'' pulls back to volume form on ''M'' restricted to the neighborhood ''U'': <math>f^*\\omega_N\\vert_V = \\omega_M\\vert_U</math>.
In one dimension, one can prove it thus:
given a volume form <math>\\omega</math> on <math>\\mathbf{R}</math>, define

column2: pulls back]] to <math>\\omega</math> under ''f'': <math>\\omega = f^*dx</math>. Concretely, <math>\\omega = f'\\,dx</math>.  In higher dimensions, given any point <math>m \\in M</math>, it has a neighborhood locally homeomorphic to <math>\\mathbf{R}\\times\\mathbf{R}^{n-1}</math>, and one can apply the same procedure.

column1: A volume form on a connected manifold ''M'' has a single global invariant, namely the (overall) volume (denoted <math>\\mu(M)</math>), which is invariant under volume-form preserving maps; this may be infinite, such as for Lebesgue measure on <math>\\mathbf{R}^n</math>. On a disconnected manifold, the volume of each connected component is the invariant.
In symbols, if <math>f\\colon M \\to N</math> is a homeomorphism of manifolds that pulls back <math>\\omega_N</math> to <math>\\omega_M</math>, then
and the manifolds have the same volume.

Volume forms can also be pulled back under [[covering map]]s, in which case they multiply volume by the cardinality of the fiber (formally, by integration along the fiber). In the case of an infinite sheeted cover (such as <math>\\mathbf{R} \\to S^1</math>), a volume form on a finite volume manifold pulls back to a volume form on an infinite volume manifold.
* [[Poincaré metric]] provides a review of the volume form on the [[complex plane]]

column4: title = Transformation Groups in Differential Geometry

column1: [[Category:Determinants]]","In [[mathematics]], a '''volume form''' on a [[differentiable manifold]] is a top-dimensional form (i.e., a [[differential form]] of top degree).   Thus on a manifold ''M'' of dimension ''n'', a volume form is an ''n''-form, a [[section (fiber bundle)
column3: 1=Ω<sup>''n''</sup>(''M'') = ⋀<sup>''n''</sup>(''T''<sup>∗</sup>''M'')}}.  A manifold admits a nowhere-vanishing volume form if and only if it is orientable. An [[orientable manifold]] has infinitely many volume forms, since multiplying a volume form by a function yields another volume form. On non-orientable manifolds, one may instead define the weaker notion of a [[Density on a manifold

column1: A volume form provides a means to define the [[integral]] of a [[Function (mathematics)
column2: function]] on a differentiable manifold.  In other words, a volume form gives rise to a [[measure (mathematics)
column3: measure]] with respect to which functions can be integrated by the appropriate [[Lebesgue integral]].  The absolute value of a volume form is a [[volume element]], which is also known variously as a ''twisted volume form'' or ''pseudo-volume form''.  It also defines a measure, but exists on any differentiable manifold, orientable or not.

column1: [[Kähler manifold]]s, being [[complex manifold]]s, are naturally oriented, and so possess a volume form.  More generally, the ''n''th [[exterior power]] of the symplectic form on a [[symplectic manifold]] is a volume form. Many classes of manifolds have canonical volume forms: they have extra structure which allows the choice of a preferred volume form.  Oriented [[pseudo-Riemannian manifold]]s have an associated canonical volume form.

A manifold is [[orientable]] if it has a [[coordinate atlas]] all of whose transition functions have positive [[Jacobian determinant]]s.  A selection of a maximal such atlas is an orientation on ''M''.  A volume form ''ω'' on ''M'' gives rise to an orientation in a natural way as the atlas of coordinate charts on ''M'' that send ''ω'' to a positive multiple of the Euclidean volume form <math>dx^1\\wedge\\cdots\\wedge dx^n</math>.
A volume form also allows for the specification of a preferred class of [[moving frame
column2: frames]] on ''M''. Call a basis of tangent vectors (''X''<sub>1</sub>, ..., ''X''<sub>''n''</sub>) right-handed if

column1: The collection of all right-handed frames is [[Group action (mathematics)
column4: general linear]] mappings in ''n'' dimensions with positive determinant.  They form a [[principal bundle
column5: principal GL<sup>+</sup>(''n'') sub-bundle]] of the [[linear frame bundle]] of ''M'', and so the orientation associated to a volume form gives a canonical reduction of the frame bundle of ''M'' to a sub-bundle with structure group GL<sup>+</sup>(''n'').  That is to say that a volume form gives rise to [[G-structure
column6: GL<sup>+</sup>(''n'')-structure]] on ''M''.  More reduction is clearly possible by considering frames that have

column1: Thus a volume form gives rise to an SL(''n'')-structure as well.  Conversely, given an SL(''n'')-structure, one can recover a volume form by imposing ({{EquationNote
column2: 1}}) for the special linear frames and then solving for the required ''n''-form ''ω'' by requiring homogeneity in its arguments.

column1: A manifold is orientable if and only if it has a volume form.  Indeed, {{nowrap
column2: SL(''n'') → GL<sup>+</sup>(''n'')}} is a [[deformation retract]] since {{nowrap
column3: 1=GL<sup>+</sup> = SL × '''R'''<sup>+</sup>}}, where the [[positive reals]] are embedded as scalar matrices.  Thus every GL<sup>+</sup>(''n'')-structure is reducible to an SL(''n'')-structure, and GL<sup>+</sup>(''n'')-structures coincide with orientations on ''M''.  More concretely, triviality of the determinant bundle <math>\\Omega^n(M)</math> is equivalent to orientability, and a line bundle is trivial if and only if it has a nowhere-vanishing section. Thus the existence of a volume form is equivalent to orientability.

column1: Given a volume form ''ω'' on an oriented manifold, the [[density on a manifold
column4: pseudo-form]] on the nonoriented manifold obtained by forgetting the orientation. Densities may also be defined more generally on non-orientable manifolds.

caption = OB-1809-P, the aircraft involved, photographed in August 2005.

column3: [[Coronel FAP Francisco Secada Vignetta International Airport
column4:
Crnl. FAP F. S. Vignetta Int'l Airport]]
[[Iquitos]], Peru}}

column1: '''TANS Perú Flight 204''' refers to a domestic scheduled [[Lima]]–[[Pucallpa]]–[[Iquitos]] passenger service, operated with a [[Boeing 737-200 Advanced]], that crashed on 23 August 2005 on approach to [[Pucallpa Airport]], {{convert
column3: mi}} off the airfield, following an [[emergency landing]] attempt because of bad weather, killing 40 of the 98 passengers and crew aboard.

column1: The aircraft involved was a 1981-built [[Boeing 737-200 Advanced
column3: registered]] OB-1809, which had been [[Aircraft lease
column4: lease]]d to TANS Perú from the South African lessor company [[Safair]] two months prior to the accident.<ref name=\"TANS confirms 57 survivors in 737-200 crash\" /> With [[manufacturer's serial number]] 22580 and powered with two [[Pratt & Whitney JT8D
column5: Pratt & Whitney JT8D-17A]] engines, the airframe had its maiden flight on 4 August 1981, and was originally delivered to [[South African Airways]].<ref name=\"ASN\">{{ASN accident
column18: accessdate=24 October 2011}}</ref> At the time of the accident the aircraft had accumulated 49,865 flight hours and 45,262 cycles,<ref name=\"Final report\"/> and was {{Age

column1: The captain was 45-year-old Octavio Perez Palma Garreta, who had 5,867 flight hours, including 3,763 hours on the Boeing 737. The first officer was 37-year-old Jorge Luis Pinto Panta, who had 4,755 flight hours, with 1,109 of them on the Boeing 737. 38-year-old Gonzalo Chirinos Delgado, a trainee pilot, was also on board. He had 2,700 flight hours, but only 61 of them on the Boeing 737.<ref name=\"TANS confirms 57 survivors in 737-200 crash\" />{{Rp
There was an unusual developing [[cold front]] in the vicinity of Pucallpa, minutes before the event took place, with [[cloud top]]s estimated to be {{convert
column3: ft}} high.<ref name=\"Final report\"/> Instead of diverting to another airport, the crew initiated the approach to Pucallpa Airport with torrential rain, hail and strong winds.<ref name=\"58 walk away from Peruvian plane crash\"/> Some {{cardinal to word
column4: 10}} minutes before the scheduled time for landing the aircraft started rocking.<ref name=\"58 walk away from Peruvian plane crash\"/> Realising that the airport could not be safely reached amid the worsening weather conditions, the pilot attempted an emergency landing. The aircraft was flying through a [[hail]]storm for the last 32 seconds of its ill-fated flight when it was seemingly taken down by a wind shear, hit tree tops, impacted terrain in a [[swamp]] located {{convert
column6: nmi}} ahead of the [[runway]] threshold, broke up as it [[Emergency landing
column7: crash landed]] and burst into flames, leaving a path of debris and flaming fuel {{convert
column11: nmi}} long.<ref name=\"Final report\"/><ref name=\"58 walk away from Peruvian plane crash\"/> The wreckage of the airplane was engulfed by the fire.<ref name=\"Final report\"/>

column4: 5}} crew (including all three flight crew) lost their lives in the accident.<ref name=\"Final report\" />{{rp
column5: 7}} Non-[[Peru]]vian occupants of the aircraft included 11 [[Americans]], one Australian, one Colombian, and one [[Spain
column6: Spaniard]]; Italians were also aboard, but the actual figures for them depend upon the source.<ref name=\"58 walk away from Peruvian plane crash\" /><ref name=\"Plane crashes in Peruvian jungle\">{{cite news
column15: df=dmy }}</ref> Most of the fatalities were recorded for passengers travelling in the front of the aircraft.<ref name=\"Final report\" /> Fifty-eight people survived the accident, many of them suffering serious injuries, mostly burns and broken limbs.<ref name=\"Final report\"/><ref name=\"Plane crashes in Peruvian jungle\"/>

column1: Investigation of the crash site was hindered by looters, who descended upon the crash and stole various elements to be sold for scrap.<ref name=\"Escape from flight 204\" /> A {{US$
column4: link=yes}} reward did succeed in securing the return of the [[flight data recorder]].<ref name=\"Data recorder from Peru plane crash found\" /> After 312 days of investigations, there were no reports of any technical malfunction.<ref name=\"Final report\"/><ref name=\"ASN\"/> The official cause of the accident was determined to be [[pilot error]] for not following standard procedures under adverse weather conditions.<ref name=\"Final report\"/> The captain took control of the plane, but the trainee pilot did not immediately monitor the instruments; as a result, the crew did not notice the rapid descent in the few crucial seconds they had where they could have avoided danger.  According to [[Aviation Safety Network]], the accident ranks among the deadliest ones that took place in 2005.<ref>{{cite web
column8: url= http://aviation-safety.net/database/dblist.php?Year=2005&lang=&page=1}}</ref> It was also the second major crash involving a TANS Perú airplane in slightly over two years.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=At least 41 dead in Peruvian plane crash
column33: quote=In January 2003, a TANS twin engine Fokker 28 turbojet, plowed into a 11,550-foot (3,465-meter) high mountain in Peru's northern jungle, killing all 42 passengers – including eight children – and four crew members aboard.

column1: Flight 204 has been the subject of a ''Reader's Digest'' story and an [[MSNBC]] documentary.<ref name=\"Escape from flight 204\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column10: url-status=dead}}</ref> The Canadian TV series, ''[[Mayday (Canadian TV series)
column11: Mayday]]'', has also produced an episode about the accident named ″Lack of Vision″.<ref name=\"Mayday\" />

column1: * [[Delta Air Lines Flight 191]], another incident involving wind shear
* [[American Airlines Flight 965]], another event involving looters at the crash site
* [[Lauda Air Flight 004]], another event involving looters at the crash site
* [[Garuda Indonesia Flight 152]], another event involving looters at the crash site
* [[Vietnam Airlines Flight 815]], another event involving looters at the crash site
* [[Southern Airways Flight 242]], another incident involving hail
<ref name=\"Data recorder from Peru plane crash found\">{{cite news
column2: title= Data recorder from Peru plane crash found
title= Mayday Season 12, Episode 5: Lack of Vision
column6: quote= Investigators face a major challenge when looters make off with the Flight Data Recorder from the crash of TANS Peru Flight 204. Wreckage allows investigators to rule out engine failure. But with no FDR, it will take all their ingenuity to reconstruct the final moments of the flight and figure out why the 737 crashed into the jungle, just 4 kilometers short of the runway.}}</ref>

column15: df=dmy }}</ref> Most of the fatalities were recorded for passengers travelling in the front of the aircraft.<ref name=\"Final report\" /> Fifty-eight people survived the accident, many of them suffering serious injuries, mostly burns and broken limbs.<ref name=\"Final report\"/><ref name=\"Plane crashes in Peruvian jungle\"/>

column1: Investigation of the crash site was hindered by looters, who descended upon the crash and stole various elements to be sold for scrap.<ref name=\"Escape from flight 204\" /> A {{US$
column4: link=yes}} reward did succeed in securing the return of the [[flight data recorder]].<ref name=\"Data recorder from Peru plane crash found\" /> After 312 days of investigations, there were no reports of any technical malfunction.<ref name=\"Final report\"/><ref name=\"ASN\"/> The official cause of the accident was determined to be [[pilot error]] for not following standard procedures under adverse weather conditions.<ref name=\"Final report\"/> The captain took control of the plane, but the trainee pilot did not immediately monitor the instruments; as a result, the crew did not notice the rapid descent in the few crucial seconds they had where they could have avoided danger. According to [[Aviation Safety Network]], the accident ranks among the deadliest ones that took place in 2005.<ref>{{cite web
column8: url= http://aviation-safety.net/database/dblist.php?Year=2005&lang=&page=1}}</ref> It was also the second major crash involving a TANS Perú airplane in slightly over two years.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=At least 41 dead in Peruvian plane crash
column33: quote=In January 2003, a TANS twin engine Fokker 28 turbojet, plowed into a 11,550-foot (3,465-meter) high mountain in Peru's northern jungle, killing all 42 passengers – including eight children – and four crew members aboard.

column1: Flight 204 has been the subject of a ''Reader's Digest'' story and an [[MSNBC]] documentary.<ref name=\"Escape from flight 204\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column10: url-status=dead}}</ref> The Canadian TV series, ''[[Mayday (Canadian TV series)
column11: Mayday]]'', has also produced an episode about the accident named ″Lack of Vision″.<ref name=\"Mayday\" />

column1: * [[Delta Air Lines Flight 191]], another incident involving wind shear
* [[American Airlines Flight 965]], another event involving looters at the crash site
* [[Lauda Air Flight 004]], another event involving looters at the crash site
* [[Garuda Indonesia Flight 152]], another event involving looters at the crash site
* [[Vietnam Airlines Flight 815]], another event involving looters at the crash site
* [[Southern Airways Flight 242]], another incident involving hail
<ref name=\"Data recorder from Peru plane crash found\">{{cite news
column2: title= Data recorder from Peru plane crash found
title= Mayday Season 12, Episode 5: Lack of Vision
column6: quote= Investigators face a major challenge when looters make off with the Flight Data Recorder from the crash of TANS Peru Flight 204. Wreckage allows investigators to rule out engine failure. But with no FDR, it will take all their ingenuity to reconstruct the final moments of the flight and figure out why the 737 crashed into the jungle, just 4 kilometers short of the runway.}}</ref>

column2: image         = Cyril Almeida - Pakistan 2020 The Year Ahead (49483598052) (cropped).jpg

column6: DD}} for living people. For people who have died, use {{Birth date

column2: alma_mater    = [[University of Oxford]], [[Lahore University of Management Sciences]]

column1: '''Cyril Almeida''' is a [[Pakistan]]i [[Journalist]] who serves as the assistant editor and columnist for ''[[Dawn (newspaper)
column3: title=Grounded Pakistani Journalist Cyril Almeida Has Goan Roots
column8: accessdate=11 October 2016}}</ref> Born and raised in [[Karachi]], Almeida received his [[B.A]] from [[Lahore University of Management Sciences
column9: LUMS]] and studied jurisprudence as a [[Rhodes Scholarship
column13: title=Cyril Almeida's principled patriotism - Times of India
column17: title=Dawn's Cyril Almeida is only the latest victim of Nawaz Sharif's dangerous game with the Pakistani army

column1: Almeida was barred from leaving Pakistan after he wrote a news article after [[2016 India–Pakistan military confrontation]], and hinted at a rift between Pakistan's civilian and military leadership.<ref name=\"BBC2\">{{cite news
column3: title=Pakistani journalist Cyril Almeida 'barred from leaving country'
column6: accessdate=11 October 2016}}</ref> Reportedly, he was put on the [[Exit Control List]].<ref name=\"FE2\">{{cite news
column8: title=Pakistan cracks down against journalist Cyril Almeida over rift with army controversy
column11: accessdate=11 October 2016}}</ref> However, after three days of criticism by media and human rights groups, his name was lifted from exit control list on 14 October 2016.<ref name=\"Guardian142\">[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/14/pakistan-journalist-cyril-almeida-travel-ban-lifted Pakistan lifts travel ban on journalist whose scoop angered army], The Guardian, 14 October 2016.</ref><ref name=\"Tribune142\">[http://tribune.com.pk/story/1198902/government-decides-strike-cyrils-name-off-ecl/ Government decides to strike Cyril’s name off ECL]</ref>

column1: Almeida belongs to a community of [[Goan Catholics]] who migrated to [[Karachi]] more than a hundred years ago. His family is said to speak [[Konkani language
column2: Konkani]] at home. Many members of the community left for western countries after the [[Partition of India
column3: Partition]], but about 15,000 members still live in Pakistan.<ref name=\"News182\"/> Reportedly, he first visited [[Goa]], India in 2012 to participate in an arts and literary festival, and then followed it up with two more visits.<ref name=\"News182\"/>

column1: He earned an undergraduate degree in economics from the [[Lahore University of Management Sciences]] in 2003. He was a [[Rhodes Scholarship
column2: Rhodes Scholar]] in 2004 and received a second BA in jurisprudence from [[Oxford University]].<ref>[http://www.goaartlitfest.com/galf2011/participatingauthors_2011.htm#Cyril_Almeida Goa Arts and Literary Festival 2013]</ref>

column1: After studying in [[England]], Almeida returned to Karachi. He practised law for about a year and changed careers to become a journalist with [[Dawn (newspaper)
column4: title=A Conversation With Dawn Editorial Writer And Op-Ed Columnist Cyril Almeida

column1: </ref> In 2013 he was promoted to Assistant Editor of Dawn.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/profile/cyril-almeida The Guardian 14 May 2013]</ref> He is also an occasional contributor to other news media.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/spotlight/pakistan-elections/2013/05/201356183748182877.html Al Jazeera 6 May 2013]</ref>

In October 2016, ''Dawn'' published a front-page article by Almeida, which said that some in the Pakistan's civilian government confronted military officials at a top-secret national security Committee meeting. They said that they were being asked to do more to crack down on armed groups, yet, whenever law-enforcement agencies took action, \"the security establishment ... worked behind the scenes to set the arrested free\". He reported that the civilians warned that Pakistan risked international isolation if the security establishment didn't crack down on terrorist groups operating from Pakistan.<ref name=AlJazeera>

column2: title=Pakistan: Cyril Almeida of Dawn 'on Exit Control List'
column6: title=Sharif govt puts scribe who reported on rift with Pak army on 'Exit Control List' - Times of India
column12: title=Reporter Who Wrote of Military Civilian Clash Says He Can't Leave Pakistan

column1: Following the news article published, both the offices of [[Prime Minister of Pakistan]] [[Nawaz Sharif]] and the Punjab Chief Minister [[Shahbaz Sharif]] denied the version of events printed in the article and called it as fabricated story.<ref name=Nation>{{cite news
column6: date=11 October 2016}}</ref> Sharif ordered authorities to take action against those responsible for publishing what he termed as a \"fabricated\" story about the military and [[Inter-Services Intelligence
column7: ISI]] after the Pakistan's chief of army staff [[Raheel Sharif]] called on him to discuss national and regional security issues.<ref name=IE>{{cite news
column8: title=Dawn journalist Cyril Almeida banned from leaving Pakistan after report on civilian govt-military meet

column1: Dawn said that the Cyril Almeida report was \"verified, cross-checked and fact-checked\" and it stood by the story. The Editor-in-Chief of Dawn urged the government to refrain from \"scapegoating\" the newspaper in a \"malicious campaign\".<ref name=\"BBC2\"/><ref name=DailyPakistan>[https://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/pakistan/story-rejected-by-pm-office-was-fact-checked-dawn-newspaper/ Story rejected by PM Office was fact-checked: Dawn newspaper], Daily Pakistan, 11 October 2016.</ref> Another Pakistani daily, ''[[The Nation (Pakistan)
column2: The Nation]]'', backed Cyril Almeida's right to write and questioned the government's ability to monopolise the discourse on \"national interest\". It also questioned why action against [[Masood Azhar]] and [[Hafiz Muhammad Saeed
column3: Hafiz Saeed]] should be considered danger to \"national security\".<ref>[http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/why-cant-action-be-taken-against-masood-azhar-hafiz-saeed-asks-pak-daily-1473473 How Is Action On Masood Azhar, Hafiz Saeed Danger To Security, Asks Pak Daily], NDTV News, 13 October 2016.</ref><ref>[http://nation.com.pk/editorials/12-Oct-2016/how-to-lose-friends-and-alienate-people How to Lose Friends And Alienate People], The Nation, 12 October 2016.</ref>

column1: On 14 October 2016, the government decided to remove his name from the exit control list.<ref>[https://tribune.com.pk/story/1198902/government-decides-strike-cyrils-name-off-ecl Government lifts travel ban on Cyril Ameida], The Express Tribune, 14 October 2016.</ref> Military sources said that they were not angry with Almeida but they were worried about government officials leaking details of the meeting. The army maintained that it was a \"false and fabricated story\" and it represented a breach of national security.
On 29 October 2016, the government held [[Pervez Rasheed]], the minister for [[Ministry of Information, Broadcasting and National Heritage (Pakistan)
column2: information]], responsible for leaking the information that led to Cyril Almeida's news report. The minister was made to resign.<ref>[http://www.dawn.com/news/1293026 Information Minister Pervaiz Rasheed asked to step down amid Dawn story probe], Dawn, 30 October 2016.</ref>

column1: On 12 May 2018, Cyril Almeida published an interview of the former prime minister [[Nawaz Sharif]], where Shaif is reported to have said, in connection with the trial of the accused in the [[2008 Mumbai attacks]]:

column2: \"Militant organizations are active. Call them non-state actors, should we allow them to cross the border and kill 150 people in Mumbai? Explain it to me. Why can’t we complete the trial?\"}}

column1: After the interview was published, the [[Pakistan Press Council]] issued a notice to ''Dawn'' stating that it published information that \"may bring into contempt Pakistan or its people or tends to undermine its sovereignty or integrity as an independent country.\" The distribution of the newspaper was subsequently blocked in parts of the country. Scholar Madiha Afzal states that the Pakistani military was behind the efforts of censorship.<ref>Madiha Afzal, [https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2018/05/30/pakistans-censorship-model/ Pakistan’s censorship model: An image- and identity-obsessed country], Brookings Institution, 30 May 2018.</ref>

In September 2018, Azhar Siddiqui, a lawyer, petitioned the [[Lahore High Court]], accusing Nawaz Sharif and former prime minister [[Shahid Khaqan Abbasi]] of treason. He alleged that Abbasi had leaked the minutes of the [[National Security Council (Pakistan)
column2: National Security Council]] to Sharif, whose statement contained such information. Almeida was asked to appear before the court and, when he failed to appear in three sittings, a non-bailable arrest warrant was issued against him. He was also placed on the Exit Control List, banning travel abroad. It was unclear whether the treason charges also applied to Almeida.<ref>[https://tribune.com.pk/story/1810710/1-lhc-issues-cyril-almeidas-non-bailable-arrest-warrant/ LHC issues Cyril Almeida’s non-bailable arrest warrant], The Express Tribune, 25 September 2018.</ref><ref>[https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/cyril-almeida-dawn-journalist-of-pakistan-to-be-arrested-on-charges-of-leaking-sensitive-information-1921731 Pak Journalist Whose Reports Angered Army To Be Arrested For Treason], NDTV News, 25 September 2018.</ref><ref>[https://indianexpress.com/article/pakistan/lahore-hc-issues-arrest-warrant-against-dawn-journalist-places-him-on-no-fly-list-5373223/ Lahore court issues arrest warrant against Dawn journalist Cyril Almeida, places him on no-fly list], The Indian Express, 25 September 2018.</ref><ref>[https://www.samaa.tv/news/2018/09/court-issues-non-bailable-arrest-warrants-for-cyril-almeida Court issues non-bailable arrest warrants for Cyril Almeida], Sama, 24 September 2018.</ref>

column1: In April 2019 Almeida was named the [[International Press Institute]]'s 2019 World Press Freedom Hero.<ref>[https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/04/pakistan-cyril-almeida-named-ipi-world-press-freedom-hero-190424094705064.html Al Jazeera 25 April 2019]</ref>

column2: image         = Cyril Almeida - Pakistan 2020 The Year Ahead (49483598052) (cropped).jpg

column1: '''Robert A. Shearer''' (born 25 May 1948) is an Australian [[professional golfer]] and [[golf course]] architect.

column2: Victoria]]. He won the 1969 [[Australian Amateur]]<ref name=sgd/> and turned pro in 1970.

column1: Shearer won the [[PGA Tour of Australia]] Order of Merit four times: 1974, 1977, 1981, 1982.<ref name=sgd>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2010-08-27}}</ref> He spent five years on the [[European Tour]] and then nine on the [[PGA Tour]].<ref name=sgd2>{{cite web
column9: accessdate=2010-08-27}}</ref> His career year was 1982 when he won the [[Australian Open (golf)
column10: Australian Open]] and his sole PGA Tour event, the [[Tallahassee Open]]. He had 18 top-10 finishes in PGA Tour events. His best finish in a [[Men's major golf championships
column11: major championship]] was a T-7 at the [[1978 Open Championship]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: Today he splits his time between his [[golf course design]] work and the [[European Seniors Tour]].<ref name=sgd2/>
