column1: '''Kasaragod district''' is one of the 14 districts in the southern [[India
column2: Indian]] state of [[Kerala]]. It's a northern most district of Kerala. [[Kasaragod]] was a part of the South Canara district of the erstwhile Madras Presidency. It then became a part of Kannur district of Kerala. Kasaragod was declared as a district on 24 May 1984.

column1: In March 2020, Kasaragod was one of the worst affected districts in Kerala by the [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in India
column4: title=Kasargod: Number of coronavirus-affected people continues to swell

column1: The district is bordered to the south by [[Kerala]]'s [[Kannur district]], and to the southeast and north by [[Karnataka]]'s districts of [[Kodagu district
column2: Kodagu]] and [[Dakshina Kannada]] respectively. To the east, the district is bordered by the [[Western Ghats]], while along the west, it is bordered by the [[Laccadive Sea]].

column1: The district, covering an area of around 1992 km<sup>2</sup>, has a population (2011 [[census]]) of 1,307,375. It has four [[taluk]]s, namely, [[Kasaragod taluk

It has three municipalities: [[Kasaragod]], [[Kanhangad]], [[Nileshwaram]] and 38 [[Gram panchayat]]s.<ref>[http://www.kasargod.nic.in/administration/pangrama.htm There are 38 Grama Panchayats in Kasaragod District] {{Webarchive
Kasaragod was known to the [[Arabs]] by the name ''Harkwillia''.<ref name=\"history\">{{cite web

Many Arab travelers who visited Kerala between the 9th and the 14th centuries visited Kasaragod, which was an important trade centre then. ''Duarte Borbosa'', the Portuguese traveler who visited [[Kumbla]], near [[Kasaragod Town
column2: Kasaragod]] in 1514, recorded rice being exported for coir to [[Maldives]].<ref name=\"history\" />

column1: Kasaragod was part of the kumbala Kingdom in which there were 64 [[Malayalam]] and [[Tulu people

When the [[Vijayanagara empire]] attacked Kasaragod, it was still under the [[Kolathiri]] [[Raja]] who had Nileshwaram as one of his capitals. During the decline of the Vijayanagara empire, the administration of this area was vested with [[Nayakas of Keladi
column2: Ikkeri Nayakas]].<ref name=\"history\" /> At the onset of collapse of the Vijayanagara empire, ''Venkappa Nayaka'' declared independence to Ikkery. Kumbla, Chandragiri and Bekal are considered to be the chain of forts constructed or renovated by [[Shivappa Nayaka]].<ref name=\"history\" />

column1: Francis Buccanan, the family doctor of [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington
column2: Arthur Wellesley]], visited Kasargod in 1800.<ref name=\"history\" /> In his travelogue, he recorded information on places like Athiraparambu, Kavvai, [[Nileshwaram]], [[Bekal]], [[Chandragiri]] and [[Manjeshwar]].<ref name=\"history\" /> Hosdurg and Vellarikundu is part of Kolathunadu  (south of Chandragiri river) and Kasaragod and Manjeshwaram is in the Tulunadu region (north of Chandragiri river).

column1: In 1763, [[Hyder Ali]] conquered Bedanoor (Bidnur), the capital of the Ikkery Naiks. His son [[Tippu Sultan]] conquered much of [[Malabar (Northern Kerala)
column2: Malabar]]. As per the ''Sreerangapattanam Treaty'' of 1792, Tippu surrendered Malabar, except [[Kanara]] to the [[British India
column3: British]]. The British occupied Kanara only after the death of Tippu Sultan.<ref name=\"history\" /> it is said that ''Kinavoor Molom'' (Sree Dharma Shashtha Temple)is belonging to ''Karinthalam'' (one of 64 Brahmin villages in old Kerala).

column1: Before the formation of Kerala, Kasaragod was a part of [[South Canara]] district of erstwhile [[Madras Presidency]]. Kasaragod became part of [[Kannur district]] following the reorganisation of states and formation of Kerala in 1 November 1956.<ref>{{cite web
column8: url-status= dead }}</ref> Kasaragod was declared a district in the year 1984. Merger of Kasargod with Kerala has been a contentious issue as there is a sizeable population which speaks Kannada and Tulu which are the languages of Karnataka. Government of India formed the Mahajan Commission on 25 October 1966 to look into the issue along with a similar issue Karnataka had with Maharashtra over Belagaavi district. The commission was headed by the third Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of India, Meher Chand Mahajan. The commission recommended that the part of the district that is to the north of Chandragiri river, which includes the Kasargod town, should be merged with Karnataka.

column1: The district is the northernmost district of the State of Kerala. Kasaragod is located at {{coord
column6: }}.<ref>[http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IN/13/Kasaragod.html Falling Rain Genomics, Inc - Kasaragod]</ref> It has an average elevation of 19  metres (62  feet).

column1: [[Ranipuram]] or Madathumala (1016m) peak is the highest peak in the Kasargod district of Kerala. It is located in the Ranipuram Wildlife Sanctuary.
According to the [[2011 census of India
column2: 2011 census]] Kasaragod district has a [[Demographics of India
column8: publisher = Census2011.co.in}}</ref> roughly equal to the nation of [[Mauritius]]<ref name=\"cia\">{{cite web

column1: }}</ref> or the US state of [[New Hampshire]].<ref>{{cite web
}}</ref> This gives it a ranking of 375th in India (out of a total of [[Districts of India
column2: 640]]).<ref name=districtcensus/> The district has a population density of {{convert
column5: PD/sqmi}} .<ref name=districtcensus/> Its [[Family planning in India
column6: population growth rate]] over the decade 2001–2011 was 8.18%.<ref name=districtcensus/> Kasaragod has a [[sex ratio]] of 1079 [[Women in India
column7: females]] for every 1000 males,<ref name=districtcensus/> and a [[Literacy in India

column1: '''Anil Dhirubhai Ambani''' (born 4 June 1959) is an Indian businessman. He is the chairman of [[Reliance Group]] (also known as [[Reliance ADA Group]]), which was created in July 2006 following a demerger from [[Reliance Industries Limited]]. He leads a number of stock listed corporations including [[Reliance Capital]],<ref>{{cite web
column11: accessdate=17 April 2014}}</ref> [[Reliance Power]] and [[Reliance Communications]].<ref>{{cite web
column16: accessdate= April 17, 2014}}</ref> Ambani, once the sixth richest person in the world, declared before a UK court on February 2020 that his net worth is zero and he is bankrupt.<ref>{{Cite news

column1: His major business interests in entertainment include 44 FM radio stations, nationwide DTH business, animation studios, and several multiplex cinemas throughout India.<ref>{{cite web
column9: url-status=dead}}</ref> After his father's death in 2002, Anil Ambani took over the reins of Reliance Group with interests in [[Telecommunication
column10: telecom]], entertainment, financial services, power and infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web
column15: accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref> Ambani is also credited with India's largest [[IPO]], that of [[Reliance Power]], which in 2008 was subscribed in less than 60 seconds, the fastest in the history of Indian capital markets to date.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In 2005 Ambani made his debut in the entertainment industry with an acquisition of a majority stake in Adlabs Films, a company with interests in film processing, production, exhibition and digital cinema. The company was renamed [[Reliance MediaWorks]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Reliance Cap buys 51% in Adlabs for Rs 360 crore
column8: title=The Reliance-Spielberg Deal: Anil Ambani's Next Blockbuster?
column11: volume=The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania
column14: title=Adlabs Films to be renamed Reliance MediaWorks

column1: In 2008 a joint venture worth US$1.2 billion with [[Steven Spielberg]]'s production company [[DreamWorks Pictures
column2: DreamWorks]] cast Ambani's entertainment business on to a global platform.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=DreamWorks to Receive Funds From Reliance
column8: date=10 April 2012}}</ref> He has contributed to the production of a number of Spielberg films, including the [[Academy Awards

column1: Ambani earned his [[Bachelor of Science]] degree from [[Kishinchand Chellaram College]] and received a Master in Business Administration at the [[Wharton School
column2: Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] in 1983.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Wharton Alumni Magazine: 125 Influential People and Ideas: Anil D. Ambani

column6: publisher=[[India TV News]]}}</ref> He is married to Indian actress [[Tina Munim]],<ref name=\"ThakurtaGhosh2014\">{{cite book
column10: title=GAS WARS: Crony Capitalism and the Ambanis
column14: isbn=978-81-928551-3-4}}</ref> and they have two sons, Jai Anmol Ambani and Jai Anshul Ambani.<ref name=\"dnaindia sons\">{{cite web
column15: title = Tina Ambani got a third baby
column18: date=18 April 2009}}</ref> Ambani is the younger brother of [[Mukesh Ambani]] and has two sisters, Nina Bhadrashyam Kothari and Dipti Dattaraj Salgaocar.<ref>{{Cite web
column20: title=Biggest secrets of Ambani family in pics

column1: * Conferred the 'Businessman of the Year 1997' award by India's leading business magazine [[Business India]], December 1998.<ref>{{cite news
* Voted 'the Businessman of the Year' in a poll conducted by [[The Times of India]] – TNS, December 2006.<ref>{{cite web
* Voted the 'Best role model' among business leaders in the biannual Mood of the Nation poll conducted by [[India Today
* Conferred 'the CEO of the Year 2004' in the [[S&P Global Platts
column4: title=Anil Ambani is Platts CEO of the Year

column1: * Conferred 'The Entrepreneur of the Decade Award' by the Bombay Management Association, October 2002.<ref>{{cite book

* Awarded the First Wharton Indian Alumni Award by the [[Wharton India Economic Forum]] (WIEF) in recognition of his contribution to the establishment of Reliance as a global leader in many of its business areas, December 2001.<ref>{{cite web

column2: Asiaweek magazine]] for its list of 'Leaders of the Millennium in Business and Finance' and was introduced as the only 'new hero' in Business and Finance from India, June 1999.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Anil Ambani makes it to Asiaweek's hall of fame

column1: In 2018, India's principal opposition party, [[Indian National Congress]], accused [[Prime Minister of India
column2: Prime Minister]] [[Narendra Modi]] of favouring Anil Ambani's defence manufacturing company over [[Hindustan Aeronautics Limited
column3: HAL]], a public sector enterprise, in a fighter aircraft deal worth INR 58,000 crores with French manufacturing firm [[Dassault]]. Ambani, several of whose companies are debt-ridden, has denied all charges of benefiting from crony capitalism.

column1: In a possibly related controversy, one of his businesses partly financed a French film in which former [[President of France
column3: Francois Hollande]]'s then-partner had acted around the same time the aircraft deal was being negotiated.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Rafale row: Reliance Entertainment confirms it paid 1.4 million Euros for film by Hollande's partner through partner

column4: title=DCC wants TRAI to review stand on spectrum pricing, quantum

The '''2012 Durand Cup''' was the 125th season of the [[Durand Cup]], the third oldest football tournament in the world, which is a knock-out competition held in [[India]]. [[Churchill Brothers S.C.
column2: Churchill Brothers]] were the current holders, having beaten [[Prayag United S.C.
column3: Prayag United]] in the [[2011 Durand Cup#Finals

column1: The tournament was held from 16 August to 1 September with all matches at the [[Ambedkar Stadium]] in [[New Delhi]].<ref name=DurandCupStart>{{cite web
column4: title=125th Durand Cup: Problems at the start of India’s oldest tournament

column2: Air India]] won the 2012 Durand Cup in the [[2012 Durand Cup Final
column4: Dodsal]] 3–2 on penalties after the match ended 0–0 after 120 minutes.<ref>{{cite web

column1: The Quarter-Finals of the Durand Cup shall be played between 12 teams. Five of the teams currently play in [[2012–13 I-League]], two played in the [[2012 I-League 2nd Division]] and one currently play in the [[Mumbai Football League]]. The other four spots would have been taken up by the top three teams from the preliminary round plus one service team. However, on 22 August 2012 it was announced that [[Hindustan Aeronautics Limited S.C.
column2: HAL SC]] would withdraw from the tournament (along with [[Churchill Brothers S.C.]] who withdrew before the initial list of teams was released) and thus freeing an extra space. So in order to fill it up the Durand Football Committee decided to qualify the four teams remaining in the preliminary rounds.<ref name=DurandSponsor>{{cite web
column5: title=Durand gets sponsor but Churchill pull out
column8: accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref> Therefore, [[Delhi United FC]], [[FC Punjab Police]], Assam Rifles FC, and CRPF FC will qualify directly for the Quarter-Finals.<ref name=DurandSponsor/>

column11: header4=Services at nearby Franklin Street station

column2: name = Chicago and North Western Railway, Passenger and Freight Depots

column1: '''Madison station''' is a former railroad station in [[Madison, Wisconsin]]. The station served passenger and freight trains of the [[Chicago and North Western Railway]] (C&NW). Passenger service ended in 1965 and the passenger station and freight depot was bought by [[Madison Gas and Electric]] (MGE) and has been renovated to serve as offices. The station and freight depot are listed as contributing properties on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] [[East Wilson Street Historic District]]. The [[Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad]] (commonly known as the Milwaukee Road) had tracks paralleling the C&NW and also had a nearby passenger station.

The first railroad entering Madison was the Milwaukee and Mississippi Railroad, a predecessor of the Milwaukee Road. Their depot was established on the west side of Madison in 1854.<ref name=\"West\">{{cite web
column2: title=West Madison Depot, Chicago, Milwaukee, and St. Paul Railway
column14: work=[[NRHP]] Inventory-Nomination Form}}</ref> The Chicago and North Western constructed a line to Madison in 1864 from the south, crossing [[Lake Monona
column15: Monona Bay]]. The first passenger station on the site was established in 1871.<ref>{{cite book
column24: page=58–59}}</ref> Due to the proximity of the Milwaukee Road, the C&NW originally wanted to construct an [[union station]] in the area. The Milwaukee Road declined and built their own depot.<ref name=\"NRHP\">{{cite web
column35: title=Madison, a History of the Formative Years

column1: Madison eventually became a junction point for the Chicago and North Western, as lines were completed north to [[Baraboo, Wisconsin
column2: Baraboo]] and [[Minneapolis]]. Other lines to [[Lancaster, Wisconsin
column3: Lancaster]] and [[Milwaukee]] were completed in the early 1800s. A new station was completed in the same location in 1885, and included a hotel and dining room within the structure.<ref name=\"NRHP\"/>

column1: After the opening of a new Milwaukee Road [[Milwaukee Road Depot (Madison, Wisconsin)
column2: depot]] in West Madison, the C&NW made plans for a new larger station, costing [[USD
column3: $]]500,000. Leaders in the government of Madison were in support of the plan, but nearby business owners and residents objected. These objections were due to the plan that would close the [[level crossing
column4: crossing]] of Blount Street to allow for expanded [[railroad platform
column5: platforms]]. A series of legal proceedings ending up costing 10 years before the C&NW revised plans.<ref name=\"NRHP\"/><ref name=\"Formative\"/>{{rp

column1: The scaled-down station opened in 1910, at a cost of $250,000, and the Blount Street crossing remains open to this day.<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=April 12, 2020}}</ref> A freight depot was also built [[circa
column8: c.]] 1908, just northwest of the station.<ref name=\"NRHP\"/> The new station was a success, and was described in 1915 as a \"bustling, buzzing, exciting hub of activity.\"<ref name=\"NRHP\"/>  The station served local and named passenger trains, such as the ''Duluth–Superior Limited'', ''The Mountaineer'', and the ''The Viking.''<ref name=\"Classic\">{{cite magazine
column16: title=Remembering the C&NW in Madison}}</ref> With the introduction of [[streamliner]] trains, Madison was served by the ''[[Minnesota 400]]'', later renamed the ''Dakota 400'' and ''Rochester 400''. The ''[[Twin Cities 400]]'' from Chicago–Minneapolis used the faster line through Milwaukee, with a connection to the ''Minnesota 400'' at [[Wyeville, Wisconsin
column28: title=Wisconsin DOT and Amtrak: Heading for Madison?
column33: url-status=live}}</ref> The station was also used for special trains for [[Wisconsin Badgers football
column34: University of Wisconsin football]] games.<ref name=\"NRHP\"/>

column1: Intercity passenger trains in the United States declined after [[World War II]], with fierce competition from the automobile and airplanes. The ''Rochester 400'' made its last run on July 23, 1963.<ref>{{cite news
column8: title=Day in History: The Rochester “400” makes its last run today
column9: author=<!--No author listed-->}}</ref> This left Madison with only one C&NW operated train—an unnamed local train to Chicago.<ref>{{cite
column14: date=June 22, 1964}}</ref> This too was discontinued on June 21, 1965. [[Madison Gas and Electric]] (MGE) bought the passenger and freight station later that month for $390,000.<ref>{{cite book
column22: ISBN=0870208845}}</ref> MGE moved their main offices to the complex in 1983, and renovated the interior, while keeping the exterior [[facade]] of the passenger station.<ref name=\"NRHP\"/> The surrounding [[East Wilson Street Historic District
column23: area]] was listed as a [[Historic districts in the United States
column24: historic district]] in 1986, and the property was listed on the Wisconsin State Register of Historic Places in 1989.<ref name=\"NRHP\"/><ref>{{cite web

column1: The 1910 station was built as a partial [[railroad terminal
column2: stub end terminal]], with two [[through track]]s connecting to the west. This configuration allowed for separate tracks that would be terminating at Madison, and avoided congestion.<ref name=\"Classic\"/> However, the [[Madison, Wisconsin#Geography
column3: geography of Madison]] still required trains from Milwaukee to perform a backup move in order to access the northern line to Minneapolis.<ref name=\"Journal\"/> The structure was designed by the firm [[Frost & Granger]], who was notable for designing other railroad buildings such as the [[Chicago and North Western Terminal]] in Chicago. The two-story [[neoclassical architecture
column4: neoclassical]] structure was made from [[Bedford stone]] and was designed to be similar to the Chicago terminal.<ref name=\"NRHP\"/>

column1: The nearby freight depot was built on the corner of Blair and Railroad Streets. It is two stories tall and made from red brick, with large rounded windows. A [[Railway roundhouse
column2: roundhouse]] was also built to the east of the station, and became notable with a boiler of a steam engine exploded in 1898.<ref>{{cite web
column7: location=Madison}}</ref> The two tracks of the C&NW intersected a single track of the Milwaukee Road with an unique [[diamond crossing]] within a grade crossing of Blair Street.<ref name=\"NRHP\"/> Only one track currently remains, and is operated by the [[Wisconsin and Southern Railroad]].<ref>{{cite map

column1: The '''Franklin Street station''', also known as '''East Madison station''', was a [[Milwaukee Road]] station. It was located at 501 East Wilson Street, one [[city block
column2: block]] west from the C&NW station. The first station on the site was built in 1869.<ref name=\"West\"/><ref name=\"Formative\"/>{{rp
column3: 124}} This was replaced with a 1886 structure in a [[Victorian Gothic]] style, in order to compete with the new C&NW station.<ref name=\"NRHP\"/> It served trains from Madison to [[Portage, Wisconsin
column4: Portage]] and [[Milwaukee]], including the ''On Wisconsin''.<ref>{{cite book
column10: section=[[Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad]]}}</ref> The station was demolished in 1952, and all Milwaukee Road passenger service shifted to the still-standing [[Milwaukee Road Depot (Madison, Wisconsin)

column2: The freight depot, northwest of the station in 2020.

column1: *[http://www.trainweb.org/rshs/VRP%20Madison%20CNW%20Pt1.htm Madison, Wisconsin Vintage Rail Photos – TrainWeb (Part 1)]
*[http://www.trainweb.org/rshs/VRP%20Madison%20CNW%20Pt2.htm Madison, Wisconsin Vintage Rail Photos – TrainWeb (Part 2)]

column4: title=The Sudbury Fight, April 21, 1676: an Address delivered before the Society of Colonial Wars at the Battle Ground, Sudbury, Massachusetts, June 17, 1897

column1: The '''Attack on Sudbury,''' also known as '''The Sudbury Fight''' (April 21, 1676), was a battle of [[King Philip's War]], fought in what is today [[Sudbury, Massachusetts
column2: Sudbury]] and [[Wayland, Massachusetts]], when approximately five hundred [[Wampanoag]], [[Nipmuc]], and [[Narragansett people
column3: Narragansett]] [[Native Americans in the United States
column4: Native Americans]] raided the frontier settlement of Sudbury in [[Massachusetts Bay Colony]]. Disparate companies of [[English people
column6: militiamen]] from nearby settlements marched to the town's defense, two of which were drawn into Native ambushes and suffered heavy losses. The battle was the last major Native American victory in King Philip's War before their final defeat in southern [[New England]] in August 1676.

column1: The winter of 1676 brought a lull in the fighting of King Philip's War in eastern [[Massachusetts]], but come spring Native American forces resumed their raids on the area's [[Puritans
column2: Puritan]] towns. The Native coalition attacked the strategically significant fort at [[Marlborough, Massachusetts]] on both March 16 and April 7, destroying most of the settlement and forcing a partial evacuation of its residents. In response to these attacks, as well as the recent abandonment of [[Lancaster, Massachusetts
column4: Groton]], the colonial Council of War dispatched Captain Samuel Wadsworth and fifty men to Marlborough to reinforce the frontier. Wadsworth's company passed through Sudbury on the evening of April 20.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite book
column7: title=King Philip's War: The History and Legacy of America's Forgotten Conflict

column1: Meanwhile, a large group of Native warriors departed the Nipmuc stronghold of [[Mount Wachusett]] and gathered on Pompositticut Hill (also known as Summer Hill in what is now [[Maynard, Massachusetts]]). After a [[pow wow]],<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Narrative of the Captivity and Restoration of Mrs. Mary Rowlandson
column11: access-date=}}</ref> the group decided to attack Sudbury instead of [[Concord, Massachusetts
column12: Concord]].<ref name=\"Gutteridge\">Gutteridge, William H. (1921). ''A Brief History of the Town of Maynard, Massachusetts''. Maynard, MA: Town of Maynard, p. 13-16 [https://books.google.com/books?id=zCwWAAAAYAAJ]</ref> Tradition holds that [[Metacomet]] led the Native army at the Sudbury Fight,<ref name=\":4\" /> though no primary sources corroborate it. Local historians have suggested<ref name=\":4\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=King Philip's War and the Sudbury Fight
column22: access-date=}}</ref> that Nipmuc [[sachem]] [[Muttawmp]] held overall command.

column1: Native forces infiltrated Sudbury during the night<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite book
column4: title=Flintlock and Tomahawk: New England in King Philip's War
column9: pages=173}}</ref> and attacked at dawn, burning houses and barns, as well as killing \"several persons,\" according to Puritan historian [[William Hubbard (clergyman)
column18: pages=149}}</ref> Many English residents of Sudbury (most of whom lived on the east bank of the [[Sudbury River]], in present-day Wayland) abandoned their homes and sought refuge in the town's fortified [[Garrison house
column19: garrison houses]].<ref name=\":4\" /> The Natives besieged the Haynes garrison house on Water Row Road all morning<ref name=\":6\" /> but faced a stout defense from the English civilians within. At one point the Natives rolled a flaming cart full of [[flax]] downhill toward the garrison, only for the contraption to hit a rock and spill over before doing any damage.<ref>{{Cite book
column22: title=They Shall Not Tamely Give It Up
column27: pages=65}}</ref> The Haynes garrison held throughout the battle, though authors George Ellis and John Morris have speculated that the siege was a [[feint]] meant to draw English reinforcements to the area.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: \"Hearing the alarm,\"<ref name=\":3\" /> about a dozen men of Concord marched to Sudbury's defense. They were ambushed and massacred within full view of the defenders of the Haynes garrison. Only one of the Concord men escaped with his life,<ref name=\":0\" /> and the dead were buried in a mass grave just east of [[Old Town Bridge (Wayland, Massachusetts)
Flushed with victory, Native forces crossed the river and set about pillaging the central settlement of Sudbury. Shortly before noon, English militiamen from [[Watertown, Massachusetts
column2: Watertown]] under the command of Captain Hugh Mason arrived and successfully repelled the raiding party.<ref name=\":0\" />

column5: A depiction of the attack on the town]]

column1: As Mason took back control of the town, Captain Wadsworth approached from the west with about seventy men,<ref name=\":5\" /> his numbers bolstered by Captain Samuel Brocklebank's garrison at Marlborough. Wadsworth's men had rested only briefly in Marlborough before their march back east to defend Sudbury; they were hungry, exhausted, and completely ignorant of their enemy's position.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web
column3: title=The Sudbury Fight, 1676: A Decisive Native American Victory in King Philip's War
column11: access-date=}}</ref> A mile from town, Wadsworth's men spotted about a hundred armed Natives darting off into the woods. Believing that \"these they might easily deal with,\"<ref name=\":3\" /> the militia set off in pursuit.

column1: The Natives led the militia to the low ground between Goodman's Hill and Green Hill in present-day Sudbury, where they sprang an ambush, surrounding the small English force. Wadsworth fought his way to the summit of Green Hill, ordering his men to form a square, and repulsed multiple Native charges.<ref name=\":3\" /> The fighting went on all afternoon.<ref name=\":2\" /> The Watertown militia and two companies of English cavalry repeatedly attempted to rescue Wadsworth, but ultimately failed to break the Native envelopment and were forced to retreat.<ref name=\":4\" />

Native warriors then set fire to the dry brush of the hill, choking Wadsworth's beleaguered company with smoke.<ref name=\":0\" /> In a panic, the English broke and ran. Half the militiamen were killed in the [[rout]], including Wadsworth and Brocklebank.<ref name=\":4\" /> The survivors fled south toward the Goodenow garrison house on [[Boston Post Road]], where Mason's company and the cavalry were regrouping. Thirteen or fourteen militiamen also took refuge in the fortified Noyes [[Gristmill
column2: grist mill]] until they were eventually rescued.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: According to [[Increase Mather]], the Natives took \"five or six of the English alive\" and \"stripped them naked, and caused them to run the gauntlet, whipping them after a cruel and bloody manner, and then threw hot ashes upon them; cut the flesh of their legs, and put fire into their wounds, delighting to see the miserable torments of wretched creatures.\"<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite book
column4: title=A Brief History of the War With the Indians in New England
column9: pages=45}}</ref> Hubbard also claims English captives were tortured,<ref name=\":3\" /> but [[Mary Rowlandson]], a captive of the sachem [[Weetamoo]] who was present in the Native camp during the battle, makes no mention of it in her memoirs.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: As night fell, Native forces withdrew from Sudbury. Early the next day, English soldiers, together with a group of allied [[Praying Indian
column2: Praying Indians]], set out to the battlefield to bury the dead.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1:
Rowlandson claims that despite their victory, morale among the Native coalition was low after the Sudbury Fight:
\"They came home without that rejoicing and triumphing over their victory which they were wont to show at other times; but rather like dogs (as they say) which have lost their ears. Yet I could not perceive that it was for their own loss of men. They said they had not lost above five or six; and I missed none, except in one wigwam. When they went, they acted as if the Devil had told them that they should gain the victory; and now they acted as if the Devil had told them they should have a fall. Whither it were so or no, I cannot tell, but so it proved, for quickly they began to fall, and so held on that summer, till they came to utter ruin.\"
Hubbard and Mather disagree with Rowlandson, putting the Native dead at a \"hundred and twenty,\" and in the autumn of 1676, prominent citizens of Sudbury recounted that they had made a \"considerable slaughter\"{{Cite web
column3: title=Letter From the Citizens of Sudbury to the General Court of Boston, October 1676
column11: access-date=}}</ref> of Native attackers. On the morning of April 22, Native warriors taunted militiamen in Marlborough by shouting seventy-four times to indicate the number of their enemy they believed they had killed at Sudbury.<ref name=\":0\" />

column3: Harvard College]]) dedicated a memorial stone over the mass grave where his father had been buried alongside his men.<ref name=\":0\" /> The stone incorrectly dates the battle to April 18, likely an error of Hubbard's<ref name=\":3\" /> that was subsequently reprinted (both Mather<ref name=\":5\" /> and the citizens of [[17th century]] Sudbury themselves<ref name=\":6\" /> state that the battle took place on April 21). In 1852, the remains of Wadsworth's militia were excavated and reinterred fifty feet north<ref name=\":0\" /> to the site of a new monument near the base of Green Hill.

column1: A handful of other monuments and markers in Sudbury and Wayland commemorate the Sudbury Fight, most of which were erected in the 1930s to celebrate Massachusetts's [[tricentennial]]. The battlefield around Goodman's Hill and Green Hill is now the site of an affluent residential neighborhood.<ref name=\":4\" />

column2: caption           = An artist's rendition of the ambush of Wadsworth's men

column3: title=The Sudbury Fight, 1676: A Decisive Native American Victory in King Philip's War
column11: access-date=}}</ref> A mile from town, Wadsworth's men spotted about a hundred armed Natives darting off into the woods. Believing that \"these they might easily deal with,\"<ref name=\":3\" /> the militia set off in pursuit.

column1: The Natives led the militia to the low ground between Goodman's Hill and Green Hill in present-day Sudbury, where they sprang an ambush, surrounding the small English force. Wadsworth fought his way to the summit of Green Hill, ordering his men to form a square, and repulsed multiple Native charges.<ref name=\":3\" /> The fighting went on all afternoon.<ref name=\":2\" /> The Watertown militia and two companies of English cavalry repeatedly attempted to rescue Wadsworth, but ultimately failed to break the Native envelopment and were forced to retreat.<ref name=\":4\" />

Native warriors then set fire to the dry brush of the hill, choking Wadsworth's beleaguered company with smoke.<ref name=\":0\" /> In a panic, the English broke and ran. Half the militiamen were killed in the [[rout]], including Wadsworth and Brocklebank.<ref name=\":4\" /> The survivors fled south toward the Goodenow garrison house on [[Boston Post Road]], where Mason's company and the cavalry was regrouping. Thirteen or fourteen militiamen also took refuge in the fortified Noyes [[Gristmill
column2: grist mill]] until they were eventually rescued.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: According to [[Increase Mather]], the Natives took \"five or six of the English alive\" and \"stripped them naked, and caused them to run the gauntlet, whipping them after a cruel and bloody manner, and then threw hot ashes upon them; cut the flesh of their legs, and put fire into their wounds, delighting to see the miserable torments of wretched creatures. Thus [the Indians] are the perfect children of the Devil.\"<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite book
column4: title=A Brief History of the War With the Indians in New England
column9: pages=45}}</ref> Hubbard also claims English captives were tortured,<ref name=\":3\" /> but [[Mary Rowlandson]], a captive of the sachem [[Weetamoo]] who was present in the Native camp during the battle, makes no mention of it in her memoirs.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: As night fell, Native forces withdrew from Sudbury. Early the next day, English soldiers, together with a group of allied [[Praying Indian
column2: Praying Indians]], set out to the battlefield to bury the dead.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1:
Rowlandson claims that despite their victory, morale among the Native coalition was low after the Sudbury Fight:
\"They came home without that rejoicing and triumphing over their victory which they were wont to show at other times; but rather like dogs (as they say) which have lost their ears. Yet I could not perceive that it was for their own loss of men. They said they had not lost above five or six; and I missed none, except in one wigwam. When they went, they acted as if the Devil had told them that they should gain the victory; and now they acted as if the Devil had told them they should have a fall. Whither it were so or no, I cannot tell, but so it proved, for quickly they began to fall, and so held on that summer, till they came to utter ruin.\"
Hubbard and Mather disagree with Rowlandson, putting the Native dead at a \"hundred and twenty,\" and in the autumn of 1676, prominent citizens of Sudbury recounted that they had made a \"considerable slaughter\"{{Cite web
column3: title=Letter From the Citizens of Sudbury to the General Court of Boston, October 1676
column11: access-date=}}</ref> of Native attackers. On the morning of April 22, Native warriors taunted militiamen in Marlborough by shouting seventy-four times to indicate the number of their enemy they believed they had killed at Sudbury.<ref name=\":0\" />

column3: Harvard College]]) dedicated a memorial stone over the mass grave where his father had been buried alongside his men.<ref name=\":0\" /> The stone incorrectly dates the battle to April 18, likely an error of Hubbard's<ref name=\":3\" /> that was subsequently reprinted (both Mather<ref name=\":5\" /> and the citizens of [[17th century]] Sudbury themselves<ref name=\":6\" /> state that the battle took place on April 21). In 1852, the remains of Wadsworth's militia were excavated and reinterred fifty feet north<ref name=\":0\" /> to the site of a new monument near the base of Green Hill.

column1: A handful of other monuments and markers in Sudbury and Wayland commemorate the Sudbury Fight, most of which were erected in the 1930s to celebrate Massachusetts's [[tricentennial]]. The battlefield around Goodman's Hill and Green Hill is now the site of an affluent residential neighborhood.<ref name=\":4\" />

column8: date=21 February 2009}}</ref> is Chairman and CEO of the Hyde Park Entertainment Group, and was formerly CEO of National Geographic Films.

column1: An internationally renowned award-winning producer, Amritraj has made over 100 films during the span of his 35-year career, with worldwide revenues in excess of $2 billion.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2019-07-03}}</ref> He has partnered with every major studio in Hollywood and produced films starring the likes of Dwayne \"The Rock\" Johnson,<ref>{{Cite web
column18: title=It Is The Time Of Disruption: Ashok Amritraj
column23: access-date=2019-07-03}}</ref> Bruce Willis, Sandra Bullock, Sylvester Stallone, Angelina Jolie, Cate Blanchett, Dustin Hoffman, Andrew Garfield, Steve Martin, Antonio Banderas,<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=It Is The Time Of Disruption: Ashok Amritraj
column32: title=Toronto: Elmore Leonard’s ‘Life Of Crime’ Near U.S. Deal With Lionsgate/Roadside
column42: title=\"Ghost Rider 2\" poised to ignite lackluster franchise

column1: Amritraj’s extraordinary career from Wimbledon tennis player to billion dollar Hollywood producer (chronicled in his autobiography Advantage Hollywood<ref>{{Cite book
column9: pages=}}</ref>) is matched only by his commitment to education, diversity, and gender equality. Dedicating a significant amount of his time to philanthropic endeavors worldwide, in 2016 Amritraj was appointed as the first United Nations India Goodwill Ambassador for the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Hyde Park Entertainment’s Ashok Amritraj on His New Role as India Goodwill Ambassador
column19: access-date=2019-07-03}}</ref> In December 2018, by decree of the President of the Republic of France, Amritraj was appointed a Chevalier (Knight) of the Ordre National du Merité.<ref>{{Cite web
column21: title=Ashok Amritraj Decorated by French Government

column1: Amritraj has grown Hyde Park into a cutting-edge independent alternative to the traditional Hollywood system, fully realizing his vision for a progressive global company that incorporates the most essential elements of a full-fledged studio. Hyde Park’s mandate encompasses feature film, television, digital, documentary, and local language content, with the Company possessing development, production, and financing capabilities in addition to handling worldwide sales and marketing.
Amritraj has had box office hits such as [[Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance]], starring Nicolas Cage,<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Movie Projector: 'Ghost Rider' sequel to scorch competition
column9: Bringing Down the House]], starring Steve Martin,<ref>{{Cite web
column26: Walking Tall]] starring The Rock, and many more, as well as critically acclaimed titles including [[99 Homes]] starring Andrew Garfield and Michael Shannon, [[Blue Valentine (film)
column27: Blue Valentine]] starring Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams,<ref>{{Cite web
column29: title=Right Cinema: Blue Valentine is an Indie Film
column32: access-date=2019-07-03}}</ref> and [[Shopgirl]], starring Steve Martin and Claire Danes.<ref>{{Cite web
column34: title=Fox takes international on Hyde Park ‘Shopgirl’

column1: Amritraj’s current projects include: supernatural thriller, [[Prey (2019 American film)
column2: Prey]], in partnership with Blumhouse Productions,<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Hyde Park-Image Nation & Blumhouse Partner For ‘Prey’
column12: access-date=2019-07-03}}</ref> Pashmina, a Major Animated Musical in partnership with Netflix, to be directed by Gurinder Chadha and with music by Oscar-winner A.R. Rahman,<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=Netflix Teams With Gurinder Chadha & Ashok Amritraj’s Hyde Park To Turn Nidhi Chanani Graphic Novel ‘Pashmina’ Into Animated Musical
column22: access-date=2019-07-03}}</ref> and Fordlandia, a Television event series, to be directed by Werner Herzog at AMC Studios.<ref>{{Cite web
column24: title=‘Fordlandia’ Novel Being Adapted For TV; Werner Herzog To Direct

column1: Hyde Park Entertainment Group and its artists have received awards and recognition from the major award shows and film festivals including the Oscars, the BAFTA awards, the Emmys, the Independent Spirit Awards, the Cannes Film Festival, the Golden Globes, and many more.
Amritraj serves on the Producers Executive Board of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2019-07-03}}</ref> and on the advisory board for the Dodge Film School at Chapman University.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=Dodge College Moves Up to #6 Spot in The Hollywood Reporter’s Annual Ranking of Top 25 Film Schools - Maintains ‘Top 10’ Status for 5th Consecutive Year
column9: website=Dodge College of Film and Media Arts
column11: access-date=2019-07-03}}</ref> In 2015, he was bestowed an honorary Doctorate of the Arts from the University of East London.<ref>{{Cite news
column13: title=Ashok Amritraj awarded honorary doctorate by a London Varsity

column1: Ashok lived in Chennai his mother's name is Maggie Dhairyam and father's name is Robert Amritraj. He has two brothers, [[Vijay Amritraj]] and Anand Amritraj, both international tennis players.

'''''Synoeca cyanea''''', commonly known as marimbondo-tatu, is a swarm-founding social wasp. Native to [[Brazil]] and [[Argentina]], ''S. cyanea'' is one of the largest and most aggressive species of social wasps and is feared in many rural areas.<ref name=\"Henrique-Simoes 2011\">{{cite journal

column2: title=Social wasps of Unilavras/Boqueirao Biological Reserve, Ingai, state of Minas Gerais, Brazil
journal=Journal of species lists and distribution

pages=}}</ref> It begins its colony cycle in the early spring and continues until nest abandonment.<ref name=\"Noda 2003\" /> Throughout its life, ''S. cyanea'' forage sugary substances and animal carcasses for food and wood pulp for its nest.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\" /> ''S. cyanea'' is also known for its strong venom, which is enough to cause.    [[haemolytic

column1: [[Johan Christian Fabricius]], a Danish zoologist, classified ''S. cyanea'' in 1775. The genus ''[[Synoeca]]'' is a part of the paper wasp tribe [[Epiponini]] and consists of five species (''S. chalibea'', ''S. virginea'', ''[[Synoeca septentrionalis
column3: S. surinama]]'', and ''S. cyanea''). ''Synoeca'' is a basal genus in the tribe. Cyanea, the adjective describing the species, translates to “dark blue,” referring to the metallic blue patches on the exterior of ''S. cyanea''.<ref>{{cite journal

column2: title=A Phylogenetic Analysis of Synoeca de Saussure, 1852, A Neotropical Genus of Social Wasps (Hymenoptera: Vespidae: Epiponini)

column1: ''S. cyanea'' is black with metallic blue patches on its body. In addition, ''S. cyanea'' has a red [[Clypeus (arthropod anatomy)
column2: clypeus]].<ref name=\"Henrique-Simoes 2011\"/> While other species in the genus ''Synoeca'' do not demonstrate [[caste]] differences, ''S. cyanea'' sometimes shows differentiation between the size of workers and the queen. A queen of a nest that is early in development will often be the same size as the workers and intermediates as it has not fully developed its reproductive organs. As the colony and nest grow, the queen also grows in size, due to ovarian development, until it is larger than the workers and intermediates.<ref>{{cite journal
title=Shape differences rather than size differences between castes in the Neotropical swarm-founding wasp Metapolybia docilis (Hymenoptera: Vespidae, Epiponini)
title=Evolution of Caste in Neotropical Swarm-Founding Wasps (Hymenoptera: Vespidae: Epiponini)

column1: }}</ref> When males are present, they are also smaller than the queen.<ref name=\"Noda 2003\">{{cite journal

column2: title=Morphological and Physiological Caste Differences in Synoeca cyanea (Hymenoptero, Vespidae, Epiponini) According to the Ontogenetic Development of the Colonies

column1: ''S. cyanea'' composes its nest out of a single comb with the cells directly attached to a tree.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\">{{cite journal

column2: title=Foraging Activity and Nesting of Swarm-Founding Wasp Synoeca cyanea (Hymenoptera: Vespidae, Polistinae)

pages=1–12}}</ref> These types of nests are known as astelocyttarous nests.<ref name=\"Noda 2003\"/> A corrugated, protective envelope made of wood pulp covers the nest, with the entrance on the superior portion of the nest. It is suggested that the architecture of the nest serves as protection against the predation of ants.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/>

column1: While the genus ''Synoeca'' is found from Mexico to Argentina, ''S. cyanea'' is native to almost the whole country of Brazil.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/> Typically, nests are found in the [[Restinga]] and the Atlantic Rain Forest. However, ''S. cyanea'' has been known to forage and make nests in [[mangrove]] areas.<ref name=\"De M Santos 2007\">{{cite journal

column2: title=Diversity and Community Structure of Social Wasps (Hymenoptera: Vespidae) in Three Ecosystems in Itaparica Island, Bahia State, Brazil

column1: ''S. cyanea'' starts a new colony cycle during the spring as it gets warmer. The first stage of a new colony is known as the pre-emergence state, in which workers have not been produced. No adult offspring are present and the larvae are still very young. A pre-emergent colony can have one or more queens.<ref name=\"Noda 2003\"/>

Following the pre-emergent state, the colony grows to the emergent stage. Workers are present along with larvae of different ages and multiple adult generations. In nests with fewer queens, intermediate females can be found.<ref name=\"Noda 2003\"/>
''S. cyanea'' males are present in the colony during the male-producing stage.<ref name=\"Noda 2003\"/>
Upon nest abandonment during the late summer, the colony shifts to the quiescent stage, i.e. the nest site no longer houses wasps.<ref name=\"Noda 2003\" />

The hierarchy of ''S. cyanea'' is based on physiology, specifically ovarian development. Wasps containing undeveloped filamentous [[ovariole]]s, slightly developed oocytes, or some mature oocytes are considered workers and intermediates. Wasps with well-developed and longer ovarioles with mature oocytes become queens. The number of queens in the colony determines the development of a queen’s ovaries. If there are more queens present, the ovaries are at a lower degree of development. One benefit to this is that as a swarming insect, queens with smaller abdomens are able to fly more easily  than queens with larger abdomens. This makes the queen less susceptible to predators.<ref name=\"Noda 2003\"/>

Foraging activity for the swarm-founding wasp ''S. cyanea'' begins early in the morning and stops in the evening. During the hottest hours of the day, activity of the wasps is highest. In addition to temperature, ''S. cyanea'' increase their activity with decreased levels of humidity and heightened intensities of light. While foraging, the wasps collect water for temperature control, wood pulp for building and repairing the nest, sugary substances for both the larvae and adults and finally animal protein for larvae.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/>

Following damage by rain to the nest, ''S. cyanea'' will seal a leak of water with their mouth-pieces. Individuals begin by suctioning the water from the wall of the nest and then finish by expelling the water to the exterior of the colony. The hole is then repaired using wood pulp.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/>

In ''S. cyanea'', discrimination between the queen and workers is often not determined by morphology, but by physiology. Young females in the colony can develop ovaries at different points in the cycle, so castes must be determined by the adult wasps rather than at the larval stage. Often, adult wasps will manipulate young females and suppress their ovaries because a wasp becomes a queen once she has mated. The number of queens allowed in a nest often fluctuates. When queen repopulation is not needed workerpolicing helps to prevent female egg-layers through [[Oophagy

The wasps forage for sugary substances o feed to both larvae and adult wasps.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/> Additionally, [[necrophagy]] is a common practice for swarm-founding Neotropical bees and wasps, and one species that practices this is ''S. cyanea''.<ref name=\"O'Donnell 1995\">{{cite journal

column2: title=Necrophagy by Neotropical Swarm-Founding Wasps (Hymenoptera: Vespidae, Epiponini)

doi=10.2307/2388911}}</ref> ''S. cyanea'' feed larvae the animal proteins collected.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/> The wasps are predators of the coffee-leaf-miner, ''[[Leucoptera coffeella]]''.<ref name=\"Mortari 2012\">{{cite journal
title=Pharmacological characterization of Synoeca cyanea venom: An aggressive social wasp widely distributed in the Neotropical region

column1: Characteristic to the genus, ''S. cyanea'' will sound an alarm when disturbed.<ref name=\"Mortari 2012\"/> This sound is made when the wasps scrape their mandibles on the carton of their nest.<ref name=\"O'Donnell 1997\">{{cite journal

column2: title=Gaster-Flagging during Colony Defense in Neotropical Swarm-Founding Wasps (Hymenoptera: Vespidae, Epiponini)
journal=Journal of the Kansas Entomological Society

pages=175–180}}</ref> In addition, as one of the most aggressive social wasps, ''S. cyanea'' often will bite and sting when threatened. Their barbed sting often remains in the skin as the wasp pulls away.<ref name=\"Akre 1978\">{{cite journal
title=Biology and Pest Status of Venomous Wasps

column1: ''S. cyanea'' venom is strong enough to cause [[haemolytic]] activity. [[Rhabdomyolysis]] and hemorrhage may also occur. In mice, abdominal spasms, ataxia, defecation, dyspnoea, hyperactivity, hypoactivity, sweating, and throes were observed following venom injection. ''S. cyanea'' venom also contains some antibacterial activity.<ref name=\"Mortari 2012\"/>

Human accidents with wasps can occur one of two ways. Either a human may receive no more than one or two stings, or a swarm may attack a human. Symptoms following the attack can range from inflammatory reactions to severe allergic reactions resulting in anaphylactic shock. In some cases, death may occur following several bites{{clarify
column2: date=September 2017}}<!--why should bites be significant?--> and a large amount of venom injection; however, a wasp sting typically will not produce a reaction more severe than local symptoms that affect only the skin.<ref name=\"Mortari 2012\"/>

column1: In Brazil, the fruit fly, ''Zaprionus indianus'', is a common pest species that inflicts damage to multiple types of fruit trees. Since ''S. cyanea ''may obtain many nutrients from these fruit trees, researchers have observed the predatory nature of these wasps on ''Z. indianus''. When ''S. cyanea'' detect the fruit fly larvae, they soften, remove, and transport them back to the colony. For this reason, many fruit farmers consider ''S. cyanea'' a prospective candidate for use in pest management.<ref>{{Cite journal
column3: title = Predation of Zaprinus indianus (Diptera: Drosophilidae) by the Social Wasp Synoeca cyanea (Hymenoptera: Vespidae)

Foraging activity for the swarm-founding wasp ''S. cyanea'' begins early in the morning and stops in the evening. During the hottest hours of the day, activity of the wasps is highest. In addition to temperature, ''S. cyanea'' increase their activity with decreased levels of humidity and heightened intensities of light. While foraging, the wasps collect water for temperature control, wood pulp for building and repairing the nest, sugary substances for both the larvae and adults and finally animal protein for larvae.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/>

Following damage by rain to the nest, ''S. cyanea'' will seal a leak of water with their mouth-pieces. Individuals begin by suctioning the water from the wall of the nest and then finish by expelling the water to the exterior of the colony. The hole is then repaired using wood pulp.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/>

In ''S. cyanea'', discrimination between the queen and workers is often not determined by morphology, but by physiology. Young females in the colony can develop ovaries at different points in the cycle, so castes must be determined by the adult wasps rather than at the larval stage. Often, adult wasps will manipulate young females and suppress their ovaries because a wasp becomes a queen once she has mated. The number of queens allowed in a nest often fluctuates. When queen repopulation is not needed workerpolicing helps to prevent female egg-layers through [[Oophagy

The wasps forage for sugary substances o feed to both larvae and adult wasps.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/> Additionally, [[necrophagy]] is a common practice for swarm-founding Neotropical bees and wasps, and one species that practices this is ''S. cyanea''.<ref name=\"O'Donnell 1995\">{{cite journal

column2: title=Necrophagy by Neotropical Swarm-Founding Wasps (Hymenoptera: Vespidae, Epiponini)

doi=10.2307/2388911}}</ref> ''S. cyanea'' feed larvae the animal proteins collected.<ref name=\"Elisei 2005\"/> The wasps are predators of the coffee-leaf-miner, ''[[Leucoptera coffeella]]''.<ref name=\"Mortari 2012\">{{cite journal
title=Pharmacological characterization of Synoeca cyanea venom: An aggressive social wasp widely distributed in the Neotropical region

column1: Characteristic to the genus, ''S. cyanea'' will sound an alarm when disturbed.<ref name=\"Mortari 2012\"/> This sound is made when the wasps scrape their mandibles on the carton of their nest.<ref name=\"O'Donnell 1997\">{{cite journal

column2: title=Gaster-Flagging during Colony Defense in Neotropical Swarm-Founding Wasps (Hymenoptera: Vespidae, Epiponini)
journal=Journal of the Kansas Entomological Society

pages=175–180}}</ref> In addition, as one of the most aggressive social wasps, ''S. cyanea'' often will bite and sting when threatened. Their barbed sting often remains in the skin as the wasp pulls away.<ref name=\"Akre 1978\">{{cite journal
title=Biology and Pest Status of Venomous Wasps

column1: ''S. cyanea'' venom is strong enough to cause [[haemolytic]] activity. [[Rhabdomyolysis]] and hemorrhage may also occur. In mice, abdominal spasms, ataxia, defecation, dyspnoea, hyperactivity, hypoactivity, sweating, and throes were observed following venom injection. ''S. cyanea'' venom also contains some antibacterial activity.<ref name=\"Mortari 2012\"/>

Human accidents with wasps can occur one of two ways. Either a human may receive no more than one or two stings, or a swarm may attack a human. Symptoms following the attack can range from inflammatory reactions to severe allergic reactions resulting in anaphylactic shock. In some cases, death may occur following several bites{{clarify
column2: date=September 2017}}<!--why should bites be significant?--> and a large amount of venom injection; however, a wasp sting typically will not produce a reaction more severe than local symptoms that affect only the skin.<ref name=\"Mortari 2012\"/>

column1: In Brazil, the fruit fly, ''Zaprionus indianus'', is a common pest species that inflicts damage to multiple types of fruit trees. Since ''S. cyanea ''may obtain many nutrients from these fruit trees, researchers have observed the predatory nature of these wasps on ''Z. indianus''. When ''S. cyanea'' detect the fruit fly larvae, they soften, remove, and transport them back to the colony. For this reason, many fruit farmers consider ''S. cyanea'' a prospective candidate for use in pest management.<ref>{{Cite journal
column3: title = Predation of Zaprinus indianus (Diptera: Drosophilidae) by the Social Wasp Synoeca cyanea (Hymenoptera: Vespidae)

column1: '''''Dean Spanley''''' is a 2008 British comedy drama film, with [[fantasy
column2: fantastic]] elements, from [[Miramax]], Atlantic Film Group (UK) and General Film Corporation (NZ), directed by Fijian New Zealander [[Toa Fraser]]. Set in Edwardian England, the film is based on an [[Alan Sharp]] adaptation of Irish author [[Edward Plunkett, 18th Baron of Dunsany
column3: Lord Dunsany]]'s 1936 novella ''My Talks with Dean Spanley''. It stars [[Sam Neill]] as the Dean, [[Jeremy Northam]] and [[Peter O'Toole]] as Fisk Junior and Fisk Senior respectively and [[Bryan Brown]] as Wrather.

column1: The narrative is called \"a surreal period comedic tale of canine reincarnation exploring the relationships between father and son and master and dog\".<ref>[http://www.villagefilmfestival.co.uk/films/deanspanley.html Village Film Festival]{{Dead link
column4: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Peter O'Toole said that the film's use of comedy to explore the relationship between a father and son was part of the attraction for him: \"All of us have had these difficult familial relationships and I think it's a film for all of us who understand the relationship between a father and son. It's been interesting watching how various members of the crew have been looking at the monitors during scenes, because they come up to me and say, 'I had the same thing with my father.'\"{{Citation needed

column1: In the very early 1900s, Henslowe Fisk lives beholden to his father, the difficult Horatio Fisk. The Fisk family has suffered first the loss of its younger son, Harrington Fisk (Xavier Horan), killed in the [[Second Anglo-Boer War]], shortly followed by the death of Horatio's wife. Fisk Senior is looked after by his housekeeper Mrs Brimley ([[Judy Parfitt]]) who has lost her husband. Fisk Junior reluctantly visits his father every Thursday.
One day, trying to entertain his father, Fisk Junior takes him to a lecture by a visiting [[swami]] ([[Art Malik]]) about the [[transmigration of the soul
column2: transmigration]] of souls. The lecture is also attended by the new local clergyman, Dean Spanley ([[Sam Neill]]).

column1: Later the same day Fisk Junior encounters the Dean at his father's club. A chance third meeting leads to an introduction. Fisk Junior, initially intrigued by the Dean's oddly open-minded views on reincarnation, is prompted to look beyond the Dean's appearance (that of an affable, rather bland clergyman) by his weakness for certain peculiar sensations produced by Hungarian Imperial [[Tokaji
column2: Tokay]] wine, which leads him into a dreamlike state. Working with his clever friend Wrather ([[Bryan Brown]]), an Australian \"[[conveyancer]]\", Fisk secures a batch of Tokay and the two entertain the Dean, who acts ever more strangely, starting to reveal memories of his previous life — as a [[Welsh Springer Spaniel
column3: Welsh Spaniel]]. These memories are acute and convincing, including rich feelings around food and communication with other canines, a deep distaste for cats and pigs, and the joy of serving his master. As the story unfolds, Fisk Junior comes to understand his father's background better and the two draw closer. There is a sub-plot concerning Fisk Senior's childhood that receives an unexpected resolution forming the climax of the story.

column1: * [[Ramon Tikaram]] as the Nawab of Ranjiput
* Shaughan Seymour as wine shop proprietor
* Charlotte Graham as woman in cloisters
* Hayden Downing as boy in cloisters
* Elizabeth Goram-Smith as a young lady of stature (uncredited)
The novella was optioned from the Dunsany Will Trust through Curtis Brown of London by Alan Sharp.<ref>[[Margaret Pomeranz]] speaking with [[Sam Neill]]. {{cite episode

column2: serieslink = At the Movies (Australian TV series)

column1: </ref>  Support for the production came from both English (Screen East) and New Zealand (NZ Film Commission) government agencies, with financing completed by Aramid Entertainment, General Film Corporation and Lipsync Productions. Both producers, the director, some of the lead cast (Neill was born in Northern Ireland but is associated with New Zealand), the cinematographer, the editor, the composer and a number of other members of the production crew and cast are from New Zealand.

The adapted screenplay was written by Alan Sharp, with clearance from the Dunsany Literary Estate. Trevor Johnston has written, \"If you read the original story before seeing the film ..., then see the film, what’s striking is that Sharp has not so much effected an adaptation as a reinvention.\"<ref>{{cite web
column12: df=dmy-all }} Trevor Johnston is a film critic for ''[[Time Out (company)

column1: Principal filming began at [[Wisbech]] in [[Cambridgeshire]] (including [[Wisbech Castle]] and [[Peckover House]]) on 10 November 2007, continuing for some weeks and taking in the heritage area of the Crescent, the Castle and the museum. It continued at [[Holkham Hall]] in [[Norfolk]]<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title = Exclusive: RT Visits the Set of Dean Spanley. We talk the transmigration of souls with Peter O'Toole and Sam Neill.
column8: publisher = [[Flixster]] }}</ref> and [[Elveden Hall]] in [[Suffolk]], once home to and remodelled for [[Duleep Singh
column9: the last Maharajah of Punjab]] in the years just before the film's setting. [[Elm Hill, Norwich
column10: Elm Hill]] in [[Norwich]] and the cloisters at [[Norwich Cathedral]] were also used.<ref>Norwich, Norfolk: 18 December 2007, Norwich Evening News (Kate Scotter)</ref><ref>Wisbech, Cambs: The Fenland Citizen, 21 November 2007: Hollywood Comes to Wisbech</ref>  Further filming took place in New Zealand.

column1: The movie was shot on 16 mm film and digitally, in 1:1.85 ratio, using Arri 416 and [[Arriflex D-20
column2: D-20]] cameras, with digital intermediate post-production by Lipsync Productions.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1135968/technical IMDb Technical Specifications for Dean Spanley]</ref>

column1: An original soundtrack was composed by New Zealand composer [[Don McGlashan]]. A soundtrack CD was released in New Zealand on Warner Music (NZ) 5186531802 consisting of 14 tracks and a running time of 41:05.
Background choir music was provided by the 30-voice New Zealand choir ''Musica Sacra''.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Musica Sacra records for film score

column1: Ahead of general release, ''Dean Spanley'' was shown twice at the [[2008 Toronto International Film Festival]], where it received a red-carpet gala premiere, the first New Zealand production ever to do so.<ref>{{cite web

column2: title = Toronto Gala world premiere for Dean Spanley

column1: It also had two showings at the [[London Film Festival]], and was also shown at the largest film festival in Asia, the Pusan International.
The United Kingdom general release <!-- (probably limited) --> was announced by Icon Distribution for 12 December, and a \"U\" classification issued by the [[BBFC
column2: British Board of Film Classification]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=DEAN SPANLEY rated U by the BBFC

column2: Ireland]] it was certified \"G\" and was released on the same date. The film was certified in Australia as \"G\" also, and was released 5 March 2009, and in New Zealand 26 February 2009; distribution in both Australia and New Zealand was by Paramount.

column1: In early November, the film was offered to United States distributors at the annual ''American Film Market'' (5–12 November), with two showings announced, and in early February 2009, Miramax bought the United States rights.<ref>[http://www.screendaily.com/ScreenDailyArticle.aspx?intStoryID=43106&Category= Miramax buys US rights to Dean Spanley]</ref> However, rather than opening in theatres in the U.S., it went straight to cable.
A region-2 DVD was released in 2009.<ref>{{cite video
column6: url=http://www.iconmovies.co.uk/dean_spanley/}}</ref> A region-1 DVD was released in 2010.<ref>{{cite web

column1: The novella, out of print for some years, was re-issued from [[HarperCollins]] in 2008. It included the film screenplay, set photos, publicity stills and interviews and comments from the cast, director, producers and crew members.
Receiving a standing ovation at the gala premiere, initial commentary was positive (per reviews at IMDb.com and elsewhere), with particular praise for O'Toole's performance and the final \"act\".

Reviews were generally positive, [[Rotten Tomatoes]] website gives the film a rating of 85% \"fresh\" based on 26 reviews. The critical consensus describes the film as \"Offbeat, whimsical, period-set [[shaggy dog story]] with daffy performances from Sam Neill and Peter O’Toole.\"<ref>[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/dean_spanley/ Rotten Tomatoes: ''Dean Spanley''] Accessed 10 May 2010</ref>

''Dean Spanley'' was longlisted for the 2009 [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]] awards for Adapted Screenplay (Alan Sharp) and Supporting Actor (Peter O'Toole).<ref>[http://www.altfg.com/blog/awards/bafta-nominations-longlist-2009/ ''Alt Film Guide]</ref>
